title_zh: 福音是什么？
content_zh:
福音就是「好消息」——这是整个宇宙最美好的消息！想象一下，如果你犯了一个巨大的错误，需要付出你永远无法承担的代价，突然有人站出来说「我替你付」，你会是什么感觉？这就是福音的核心。

我们的问题：罪的现实
简单来说，上帝按着祂的形象创造了我们，本意是让我们与祂有完美的关系，享受祂的爱。但我们都选择了背叛——这就是「罪」。不只是做坏事，更是我们内心想要「做自己的上帝」的叛逆态度。就像一台精密的电脑，如果核心程序出错，整个系统都会崩溃。罪让我们与创造主分离，导致死亡和永远的孤独。

上帝的解决方案：十字架的爱
但故事还没结束！上帝太爱我们了，祂不愿意看着我们永远沉沦。所以祂做了一件不可思议的事——差遣自己的独生子耶稣来到这个破碎的世界。耶稣不是来当一个好老师或道德榜样，而是来当我们的救主。祂在十字架上承担了我们所有的罪和刑罚，三天后从死里复活，证明死亡已经被彻底击败！

我们的回应：信心的礼物
那么，我们需要做什么呢？答案让很多人惊讶：不需要做什么来「赚取」这份救恩！我们只需要相信——承认自己确实需要拯救，相信耶稣已经为我们完成了一切，接受祂作为我们生命的主。就像溺水的人抓住救生圈，不是因为自己游泳技术好，而是因为知道那是唯一的希望。

生命的转变：新的开始
当你真心接受这个好消息时，几件奇妙的事会发生：你成为上帝的儿女，罪得到完全赦免，获得永恒的生命，圣灵住进你心里开始改变你。这不是说你突然变得完美，而是说你有了新的身份和新的力量来过不同的生活。

福音跟「做个好人上天堂」完全不同。如果救恩靠行为，那就像考试必须100分才及格——没人做得到！但福音说：耶稣已经替你考了满分，现在把成绩单给你。你要做的只是伸手接过来。这就是恩典——不配得的爱和礼物。这个好消息改变了亿万人的生命，今天也能改变你的！
content_en:
The Gospel means 'good news' — the best news in the entire universe! Imagine if you made a huge mistake requiring a price you could never pay, and someone stepped forward saying 'I'll pay it for you.' How would you feel? That's the heart of the Gospel.

Our Problem: The Reality of Sin
Simply put, God created us in His image, intending perfect relationship with Him and enjoyment of His love. But we all chose rebellion — that's 'sin.' Not just doing bad things, but the rebellious attitude of wanting to 'be our own god.' Like a precision computer with corrupted core programming, the whole system crashes. Sin separates us from our Creator, leading to death and eternal loneliness.

God's Solution: The Love of the Cross
But the story isn't over! God loves us too much to watch us perish forever. So He did something incredible — sent His only Son Jesus into this broken world. Jesus didn't come as a good teacher or moral example, but as our Savior. On the cross, He bore all our sin and punishment, then rose from the dead three days later, proving death was completely defeated!

Our Response: The Gift of Faith
So what must we do? The answer surprises many: nothing to 'earn' this salvation! We only need to believe — admit we truly need rescue, believe Jesus already accomplished everything for us, accept Him as our life's Lord. Like a drowning person grabbing a life ring, not because of swimming skills but knowing it's the only hope.

Life Transformation: A New Beginning
When you truly accept this good news, amazing things happen: you become God's child, sins are completely forgiven, you receive eternal life, and the Holy Spirit moves in to begin changing you. This doesn't mean sudden perfection, but a new identity and new power to live differently.

The Gospel is completely different from 'being good enough for heaven.' If salvation depended on works, it would be like needing 100% to pass an exam — nobody could do it! But the Gospel says: Jesus already scored perfect for you and hands you the report card. You just need to reach out and take it. This is grace — undeserved love and gift. This good news has transformed billions of lives and can transform yours today!

title_zh: 我怎么知道上帝是真的？
title_en: How Do I Know God Is Real?
content_zh:
这是一个超棒的问题！怀疑不代表你没有信心，反而说明你在认真思考。其实，相信上帝存在的证据无处不在，只要你愿意睁开眼睛去看。

第一，宇宙的精密设计。从银河系的壮丽到DNA双螺旋的精妙编码，这一切不可能是随机碰撞的结果。科学家发现宇宙中有超过二十个精密常数，哪怕其中一个偏差一点点，生命都不可能存在。就像看到一部手机，你不会说它是石头自然碰撞形成的，对吧？有设计，就必然有设计者。

第二，人心深处的渴望。每个人心里都有一种对公义、真爱和永恒的渴望。为什么我们看到不公平的事会愤怒？为什么我们害怕死亡却渴望永恒？这些渴望不是进化能解释的，而是上帝放在我们心中的印记。正如奥古斯丁所说，我们的心为上帝而造，除非安息在祂里面，否则永远不得安宁。

第三，历史的证据。耶稣的复活不是编造的故事，而是有大量历史证据支持的事实。超过五百人亲眼见过复活的耶稣，门徒们从胆小怕事变成不怕死的传道者，空坟墓至今无人能给出合理解释。如果复活是假的，门徒为什么愿意为一个谎言去死？

第四，改变生命的力量。两千年来，无数人因为认识上帝而生命被翻转。瘾君子戒了毒，破碎的家庭被修复，绝望的人找到了盼望。这不是心理暗示，而是真实的神在人生命中做真实的工作。

最后也是最重要的：你可以亲自经历祂。当你真诚地祷告，认真地读圣经，你会开始在生活中看到上帝的作为。信心不是盲目的跳跃，而是基于证据的信任。上帝说「你们寻求我，若专心寻求我，就必寻见」。祂不怕你的问题，祂等着你来寻找祂。
content_en:
This is an awesome question! Doubting doesn't mean you lack faith — it means you're thinking seriously. Actually, the evidence for God's existence is everywhere if you're willing to look.

First, the universe's precise design. From the majesty of galaxies to the intricate coding of DNA, none of this could be the result of random collisions. Scientists have discovered over twenty finely-tuned constants in the universe — if even one were slightly off, life couldn't exist. It's like seeing a smartphone and claiming rocks randomly bumped together to create it. Where there's design, there must be a designer.

Second, the deep longings of the human heart. Everyone has an innate longing for justice, true love, and eternity. Why do we feel outraged at injustice? Why do we fear death yet yearn for forever? These desires can't be explained by evolution — they're God's imprint on our hearts. As Augustine said, our hearts are made for God, and they're restless until they rest in Him.

Third, historical evidence. Jesus' resurrection isn't a fabricated story — it's a well-evidenced historical event. Over five hundred people saw the risen Jesus, the disciples transformed from cowards into fearless preachers, and the empty tomb remains unexplained. If the resurrection were fake, why would the disciples die for a lie?

Fourth, life-transforming power. For two thousand years, countless lives have been transformed through knowing God. Addicts freed from substance abuse, broken families restored, hopeless people finding hope. This isn't psychological suggestion — it's a real God doing real work in real lives.

Finally and most importantly: you can experience Him personally. When you sincerely pray and earnestly read the Bible, you'll begin seeing God at work in your life. Faith isn't a blind leap — it's trust based on evidence. God says, 'You will seek me and find me when you seek me with all your heart.' He's not afraid of your questions. He's waiting for you to come find Him.

title_zh: 为什么耶稣要死在十字架上？
title_en: Why Did Jesus Die on the Cross?
content_zh:
想象一下：你犯了一个天大的错误，欠下了永远还不清的债务，你完全绝望了。这时候有人站出来说「我来替你还」，而且这个人是你最爱的人。这就是耶稣在十字架上做的事情。

为什么需要十字架？因为罪的问题比我们想象的严重得多。圣经告诉我们「罪的工价就是死」（罗马书六章二十三节），而我们每一个人都犯过罪。不只是杀人放火才叫罪，撒谎、嫉妒、骄傲、自私，这些在上帝眼中都是罪。上帝是完全公义的，祂不能假装罪不存在，就像法官不能因为罪犯是自己的孩子就说「算了不判了」。罪必须被审判，代价必须被偿还。

但上帝同时也完全爱我们。这就是十字架的奥秘：公义和慈爱在十字架上完美相遇。上帝做了一件不可思议的事——祂让自己的独生子耶稣来到世上，代替我们接受罪的惩罚。耶稣没有犯过任何罪，祂是完全无辜的，但祂自愿走上十字架，承担了全人类的罪。先知以赛亚在耶稣出生七百年前就预言说「祂为我们的过犯受害，为我们的罪孽压伤」。

这不是因为耶稣软弱或被迫。恰恰相反，这是人类历史上最伟大的爱和最大的能力的彰显。耶稣说「没有人夺我的命去，是我自己舍的」。祂完全可以从十字架上下来，但祂选择留在那里，因为祂爱你。

三天后，耶稣从死里复活了！这证明死亡已经被彻底击败，罪的权势已经被打破。因为十字架，我们可以重新与上帝和好，获得完全的赦免和永恒的生命。十字架不是一个悲剧，而是宇宙间最伟大的胜利。它告诉我们：无论你做了什么，上帝的爱比你的罪更大。
content_en:
Imagine this: you made a catastrophic mistake, owed a debt you could never repay, and you're completely hopeless. Then someone steps forward and says, 'I'll pay it for you' — and that person is someone who loves you most. That's exactly what Jesus did on the cross.

Why was the cross necessary? Because the problem of sin is far more serious than we realize. The Bible tells us 'the wages of sin is death' (Romans 6:23), and every one of us has sinned. Sin isn't just murder or arson — lying, jealousy, pride, selfishness are all sin in God's eyes. God is perfectly just and can't pretend sin doesn't exist, just as a judge can't say 'never mind, no sentence' because the criminal is their own child. Sin must be judged; the price must be paid.

But God also loves us completely. This is the mystery of the cross: justice and mercy meet perfectly there. God did something incredible — He sent His only Son Jesus into the world to take the punishment for our sins in our place. Jesus never committed any sin; He was completely innocent. Yet He willingly walked to the cross, bearing all of humanity's sin. The prophet Isaiah prophesied seven hundred years before Jesus' birth: 'He was pierced for our transgressions, crushed for our iniquities.'

This wasn't because Jesus was weak or forced. Quite the opposite — it was the greatest display of love and power in human history. Jesus said, 'No one takes my life from me; I lay it down of my own accord.' He could have come down from the cross, but He chose to stay because He loves you.

Three days later, Jesus rose from the dead! This proves death has been completely defeated and sin's power has been broken. Because of the cross, we can be reconciled with God, receive complete forgiveness, and gain eternal life. The cross isn't a tragedy — it's the greatest victory in the universe. It tells us: no matter what you've done, God's love is greater than your sin.

title_zh: 怎样祷告？
content_zh:
祷告就是和上帝说话，就像跟一个最亲密的朋友聊天一样。不需要用特别高深的词，也不需要固定的姿势。你可以随时随地祷告——在上学路上、考试前、开心的时候、难过的时候。

如何开始？ 找个安静的地方和时间，不需要特别的位置，但减少干扰会有帮助。从简单的开始：「上帝，我想和祢说话。」不需要华丽的语言——开心、担心、感恩、困惑，什么都可以跟祂说。上帝已经知道你的心，祂想听的是你真实的声音。

ACTS祷告法： 一个简单的方法是ACTS（赞美-认罪-感恩-祈求）模式：A-赞美：感谢上帝是谁；C-认罪：诚实地承认自己做错的事；T-感恩：感谢上帝的恩典；S-祈求：把你的需要告诉祂。

祷告也要聆听。 祷告不只是说话，也要安静等候。祷告后花些时间安静下来，让圣灵对你的心说话。

不用担心形式。 大声祷告、默祷都行，长的短的都行。五分钟真诚的祷告胜过半小时空洞的话语。记住，祷告不是在念咒语，上帝不是自动售货机。祂是你的天父，祂更在意你的心，而不是你的措辞。有时候上帝的回答是'是'，有时候是'还没有'，有时候是'我有更好的计划'——但祂一定会回应。
content_en:
Prayer is just talking to God — like chatting with your closest friend. You don't need fancy words or a special posture. You can pray anytime, anywhere — on the way to school, before a test, when you're happy, when you're sad.

How to start? Find a quiet place and time. No special location needed, but avoiding distractions helps. Start with a simple acknowledgment: "God, I want to talk to You." No fancy words needed — excitement, worry, gratitude, confusion — bring it all. God already knows your heart; He just wants to hear your genuine voice.

The ACTS method: A simple framework: A-Adoration (praise God for who He is), C-Confession (honestly admit what you've done wrong), T-Thanksgiving (thank God for His blessings), S-Supplication (tell Him what you need).

Prayer is also listening. Prayer isn't just talking — it's also waiting quietly. After praying, spend time in silence and let God's Spirit speak to your heart.

Don't worry about format. Pray out loud or silently, long or short — it all counts. Five minutes of sincere prayer beats half an hour of empty words. Remember, prayer isn't casting a spell, and God isn't a vending machine. He's your heavenly Father who cares about your heart, not your vocabulary. Sometimes God's answer is 'yes,' sometimes 'not yet,' and sometimes 'I have a better plan' — but He always responds.

title_zh: 为什么要读圣经？
content_zh:
圣经不是一本普通的书——它是上帝写给你的信。在这个充满噪音的世界，圣经是你能听到上帝声音的地方。

为什么要读圣经？

1）认识上帝。 你想了解一个人，就要听他说话、读他写的东西。圣经就是上帝向我们说的话，通过它你会越来越了解上帝的性格、祂的爱、祂的计划。

2）认识自己。 圣经像一面镜子，帮助你看清自己——你的价值、你的问题、你被造的目的。「神的道是活泼的，是有功效的，比一切两刃的剑更快。」（希伯来书4:12）

3）生命的指南。 面对选择、困惑、压力时，圣经给你智慧和方向。「你的话是我脚前的灯，是我路上的光。」（诗篇119:105）

4）属灵的食粮。 就像身体需要食物，灵魂需要上帝的话语来成长。不读圣经的基督徒就像不吃饭的人——会越来越虚弱。

5）抵挡试探。 耶稣在旷野受试探时，用圣经的话来抵挡魔鬼。你也需要这个武器。

6）经历上帝的同在。 很多人在读经时感受到上帝的安慰、引导和力量。圣经不只是信息，更是与上帝相遇的途径。

每次读都会有新的收获，因为这是上帝活泼的话语！
content_en:
The Bible isn't an ordinary book — it's God's letter to you. In a world full of noise, the Bible is where you can hear God's voice.

Why read the Bible?

1) To know God. To understand someone, you listen to them and read what they've written. The Bible is God speaking to us — through it, you'll grow to understand His character, His love, and His plan.

2) To know yourself. The Bible is like a mirror, helping you see clearly — your worth, your struggles, your purpose. "The word of God is alive and active, sharper than any double-edged sword." (Hebrews 4:12)

3) A guide for life. When facing choices, confusion, or pressure, the Bible gives you wisdom and direction. "Your word is a lamp for my feet, a light on my path." (Psalm 119:105)

4) Spiritual nourishment. Just as your body needs food, your soul needs God's Word to grow. A Christian who doesn't read the Bible is like a person who doesn't eat — they'll grow weaker.

5) Resisting temptation. When Jesus was tempted in the wilderness, He used Scripture to fight back. You need this weapon too.

6) Experiencing God's presence. Many people encounter God's comfort, guidance, and strength while reading Scripture. The Bible isn't just information — it's a pathway to meeting God.

Every time you read, you'll discover something new, because this is God's living Word!

title_zh: 同学嘲笑我的信仰怎么办？
title_en: What If Classmates Mock My Faith?
content_zh:
在学校里因为信仰被嘲笑真的很难受，但你不是一个人。耶稣自己说过：'世人若恨你们，你们知道恨你们以先，已经恨我了'（约翰福音15:18）。使徒们也被人认为是'疯子'。这不是你的失败，反而证明你在走正确的路。

如何回应？

1）不要用愤怒回应。 试着用温柔和尊重来面对（彼得前书3:15）。你可以说：'我理解你的看法，但这对我很重要。'有时候沉默反而是最有力的回应。

2）记住你的身份。 你是上帝的孩子，你的价值不是由同学的评价决定的。他们嘲笑的不是你，而是你所信的。

3）找到你的团队。 教会的青少年团契、基督徒同学、信任的导师——不要独自承受。找到支持你的人。

4）装备自己。 学习如何回答常见的质疑。不是每个辩论都值得参与，但心里有预备会让你更有信心。

5）为嘲笑你的人祷告。 这能软化你的心，也可能改变他们。有时候，嘲笑的背后其实是好奇。

6）选择你的战场。 不是每次挑衅都需要回应。要有智慧——有时候你忠心、温柔的生命见证比任何辩论都更有力。你的生活可能是他们认识上帝的第一步。
content_en:
Being mocked at school for your faith really hurts, but you're not alone. Jesus Himself said: 'If the world hates you, know that it hated me before it hated you' (John 15:18). The apostles were thought 'crazy' too. This isn't your failure — it actually proves you're on the right path.

How to respond?

1) Don't respond with anger. Try gentleness and respect (1 Peter 3:15). You can say, 'I understand your view, but this is important to me.' Sometimes silence is the most powerful response.

2) Remember your identity. You're a child of God, and your worth isn't determined by classmates' opinions. They're mocking what you believe, not who you are.

3) Find your crew. Church youth group, Christian friends, trusted mentors — don't bear this alone. Find people who support you.

4) Equip yourself. Learn to answer common challenges. Not every argument is worth engaging, but being prepared gives you confidence.

5) Pray for those who mock you. This softens your heart and might change theirs. Sometimes mockery is actually curiosity in disguise.

6) Choose your battles wisely. Not every provocation needs a response. Your faithful, gentle life witness is often more powerful than any debate. You might be their first step toward knowing God.

title_zh: 科学和信仰矛盾吗？
content_zh:
很多人觉得科学和信仰是水火不容的对立面，但事实远非如此！历史上许多伟大的科学家都是虔诚的基督徒——牛顿研究物理学是为了理解上帝创造的规律，法拉第因着对造物主的敬畏而探索电磁学，帕斯卡既是数学天才也是深刻的神学思想家。科学和信仰不是敌人，而是好搭档。

科学研究的是「怎么运作」的问题，信仰回答的是「为什么存在」的问题。它们不是互相矛盾，而是互相补充。比如科学可以告诉你水的化学成分是两个氢原子加一个氧原子，但科学不能告诉你生命的意义是什么、爱从哪里来、人为什么渴望公义。这些是科学无法回答的终极问题，恰恰是信仰的领域。

宇宙的精密设计反而指向一位智慧的创造者。地球与太阳的距离、引力常数、原子的结构——这些数值如果有微小的偏差，生命就不可能存在。这种精确性是随机发生的概率几乎为零。

需要特别注意的是，宏观进化论仍然只是一个未被证实的假说，面临着许多严峻的科学挑战。寒武纪大爆发中几乎所有动物门类突然出现，没有足够的中间过渡化石；生物体内复杂的信息系统（如DNA编码）无法用随机突变来解释。微观进化，也就是物种内部的适应变化，确实是可以观察到的现象，比如细菌产生抗药性。但从单细胞生物到人类的宏观进化从未被直接观察到，化石记录中也缺乏关键的过渡形态。

大爆炸理论则指向宇宙有一个明确的开端——这恰恰与圣经「起初上帝创造天地」的宣告一致。在大爆炸之前是什么？科学无法回答，但圣经告诉我们：是上帝。

上帝创造了一个可以被科学研究的有秩序的世界。科学其实是在探索上帝的作品，每一个科学发现都让我们更惊叹造物主的智慧。真正的科学精神是谦卑和好奇，而不是傲慢地宣称「我们已经知道一切」。作为基督徒，我们可以大胆地拥抱科学，因为一切真理都是上帝的真理。
content_en:
Many people think science and faith are opposing enemies, but the reality is far from that! Many of history's greatest scientists were devout Christians — Newton studied physics to understand God's created laws, Faraday explored electromagnetism out of reverence for the Creator, and Pascal was both a mathematical genius and profound theological thinker. Science and faith aren't enemies; they're great partners.

Science studies 'how things work,' while faith answers 'why things exist.' They're not contradictory but complementary. For example, science can tell you water consists of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom, but science can't tell you the meaning of life, where love comes from, or why humans long for justice. These are ultimate questions science cannot answer — precisely the domain of faith.

The universe's precise design actually points to an intelligent Creator. Earth's distance from the sun, the gravitational constant, atomic structure — if any of these values were slightly different, life couldn't exist. The probability of such precision occurring randomly is essentially zero.

It's particularly important to note that macro-evolution remains an unproven hypothesis facing serious scientific challenges. During the Cambrian Explosion, nearly all animal phyla appeared suddenly without sufficient transitional fossils. The complex information systems in living organisms (like DNA coding) cannot be explained by random mutations. Micro-evolution — adaptive changes within species — is indeed observable, such as bacteria developing antibiotic resistance. But macro-evolution from single-celled organisms to humans has never been directly observed, and the fossil record lacks key transitional forms.

The Big Bang theory actually points to the universe having a definite beginning — which aligns precisely with the Bible's declaration that 'In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.' What existed before the Big Bang? Science cannot answer, but the Bible tells us: God.

God created an orderly world that can be studied by science. Science is actually exploring God's handiwork — every scientific discovery deepens our awe of the Creator's wisdom. True scientific spirit is humility and curiosity, not arrogantly claiming 'we already know everything.' As Christians, we can boldly embrace science, because all truth is God's truth.

title_zh: 考试压力大怎么办？
content_zh:
考试压力是真实的，特别是面对升学考试，上帝理解你的感受。但记住：你的价值不是由分数定义的，你的身份不是由成绩决定的。

实用建议：

1）做好准备。 信仰不是让你不学习然后等奇迹。认真学习、合理规划、寻求帮助——该复习的还是要复习，这是忠心管理上帝给你的才能。

2）祷告交托。 '应当一无挂虑，只要凡事藉着祷告、祈求和感谢，将你们所要的告诉上帝。'（腓立比书4:6）考前花一分钟安静祷告，深呼吸，把心交给祂。祷告不是迷信，而是与造物主对话。

3）保持健康。 充足的睡眠、适当的运动、合理的饮食——照顾上帝给你的身体。

4）调整心态。 尽力而为，结果交给上帝。一次考试失败不会毁掉你的人生。上帝对你的计划远大于一次考试，比你想象的更美好。

5）不要忽略属灵操练。 不要因为学习忙就忽略了读经祷告。越是压力大，越需要从上帝那里支取力量。

6）互相鼓励。 和朋友一起复习，互相祷告，分享你平安的秘诀。压力不需要一个人扛。

努力学习，但不要让学业成为偶像。
content_en:
Exam stress is real, especially facing entrance exams, and God understands how you feel. But remember: your worth isn't defined by your grades, and your identity isn't determined by test scores.

Practical tips:

1) Prepare well. Faith doesn't mean you skip studying and wait for a miracle. Study hard, plan wisely, seek help — being a faithful steward of the abilities God gave you.

2) Pray and surrender. 'Be anxious for nothing, but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known to God.' (Philippians 4:6) Take a minute before the exam to pray quietly and breathe. Prayer isn't superstition — it's conversation with the Creator.

3) Stay healthy. Enough sleep, some exercise, good food — take care of the body God gave you.

4) Adjust your mindset. Do your best, leave the results to God. One test failure won't ruin your life. God's plan for you is way bigger than one exam and better than you imagine.

5) Don't neglect spiritual disciplines. Don't skip Bible reading and prayer because you're busy studying. The more pressure you face, the more you need strength from God.

6) Encourage each other. Study with friends, pray for each other, share your secret of peace. You don't have to carry the pressure alone.

Work hard, but don't make academics an idol.

title_zh: 如何交到好朋友？
content_zh:
圣经说：'滥交朋友的，自取败坏；但有一朋友，比弟兄更亲密'（箴言18:24）。朋友的影响力巨大，特别是在青少年时期。好的朋友会帮助你成长，而不是把你拉远离上帝。

怎么找到好朋友？

1）先做一个好朋友。 主动关心别人，倾听别人，真诚待人。

2）区分密友和普通朋友。 密友应该是支持你信仰成长的人，即使不是基督徒，至少要尊重你的信仰。普通朋友可以包括各种人，这也是传福音的机会。

3）参加教会青少年团契。 这里有一群跟你有同样信仰的同龄人，属灵友谊会帮助你成长。

4）不要害怕跟非基督徒做朋友。 耶稣也跟'罪人'一起吃饭。关键是你影响他们，而不是被他们影响。参与健康的活动，避免试探的场合。

5）学会设立界限。 如果一段友谊总是让你做违背良心的事，那要勇敢说不。不要为了受欢迎而妥协原则——真正的朋友会接受真实的你。

6）记住你也在影响别人。 问问自己：我是帮助朋友更接近上帝，还是更远离上帝？

最重要的：耶稣是你最好的朋友。在你孤单的时候，祂永远不会离开你。好的友谊需要时间，不要着急。
content_en:
The Bible says, 'One who has unreliable friends soon comes to ruin, but there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother' (Proverbs 18:24). Friends have huge influence, especially during teenage years. Good friends help you grow and don't pull you away from God.

How to find good friends?

1) BE a good friend first. Care for others, listen, be genuine.

2) Distinguish close friends from casual friends. Close friends should support your faith growth — even if not Christians, they should at least respect your faith. Casual friends can include various people, and that's an evangelism opportunity too.

3) Join a church youth group. You'll find peers who share your faith. Spiritual friendships help you grow.

4) Don't be afraid to befriend non-Christians. Jesus ate with 'sinners' too. The key is that you influence them, not the other way around. Participate in healthy activities, avoid tempting situations.

5) Learn to set boundaries. If a friendship keeps pushing you to do things against your conscience, have the courage to say no. Don't compromise principles to be popular — real friends accept the real you.

6) Remember you're also influencing others. Ask yourself: am I helping friends move closer to or further from God?

Most importantly: Jesus is your best friend. When you're lonely, He will never leave you. Good friendships take time — don't rush it.

title_zh: 社交媒体和信仰
content_zh:
社交媒体是一个工具——它本身不是坏的，但可以被用好也可以被用坏。作为基督徒，如何智慧地使用它？

1）比较是快乐的小偷。 当你刷到别人的'完美生活'，记住那只是精心挑选的片段。你的价值在上帝面前已经被完全确定了，不需要跟任何人比较。

2）管理你的时间。 社交媒体容易成瘾，偷走我们与上帝和真实人际关系的时间。如果你花在手机上的时间比跟上帝相处的时间多得多，需要调整了。设定界限，定期'禁食'社交媒体。

3）小心你消费的内容。 不合适的内容会悄悄影响你的思想。'你们要谨守你们的心'（箴言4:23）。发布前也问自己：这会让人更认识基督吗？避免抱怨、炫耀、传谣言。'污秽的言语一句不可出口，只要随事说造就人的好话。'

4）积极使用。 分享鼓励的经文、恩典的见证、有意义的内容，传播正能量。社交媒体也是见证的新平台。

5）避免网络争论。 特别是关于政治或争议话题，私下对话比公开辩论更有效。

6）线下关系更重要。 再多的点赞也比不上一个真实的拥抱。定期放下手机，和真实的人在一起。

记住：网络留痕永远存在，今天发的内容十年后还可能被看到。
content_en:
Social media is a tool — it's not bad in itself, but it can be used well or poorly. As a Christian, how do you use it wisely?

1) Comparison is the thief of joy. When you see others' 'perfect lives,' remember those are curated highlights. Your worth is already fully established before God — no comparison needed.

2) Manage your time. Social media is addictive, stealing time from God and real relationships. If you spend way more time on your phone than with God, it's time to adjust. Set boundaries, regularly 'fast' from social media.

3) Be careful what you consume. Inappropriate content quietly shapes your thinking. 'Guard your heart' (Proverbs 4:23). Before posting, ask yourself: will this help people know Christ better? Avoid complaining, showing off, spreading rumors. 'Let no unwholesome word proceed from your mouth, but only what builds others up.'

4) Use it positively. Share encouraging verses, grace testimonies, meaningful content. Social media is also a new platform for witness.

5) Avoid online arguments. Especially about politics or controversial topics — private conversations are more effective than public debates.

6) Offline relationships matter more. No amount of likes beats a real hug. Regularly put down your phone and be with real people.

Remember: the internet leaves permanent traces — what you post today might be seen ten years from now.

title_zh: 我总是犯同样的罪怎么办？
title_en: I Keep Sinning the Same Way
content_zh:
首先，你需要知道你不是唯一一个有这种挣扎的人。使徒保罗——写了新约将近一半书信的属灵巨人——也坦诚地说过「我所愿意的善，我反不做；我所不愿意的恶，我倒去做」（罗马书七章十九节）。连保罗都有这样的挣扎，何况是我们呢！但这绝对不是你放弃或者自暴自弃的理由。

第一，不要绝望。上帝的恩典够你用。你跌倒一百次，祂会一百零一次把你扶起来。祂对你的爱不是建立在你的表现上，而是建立在基督已经完成的救赎上。你犯罪不会让上帝不爱你，就像孩子摔倒不会让父母不爱孩子一样。

第二，认罪要具体。不是笼统地说「上帝求你赦免我的罪」，而是诚实地、具体地承认你做了什么。这不是因为上帝不知道，而是具体的认罪帮助你真正面对自己的问题，也让你更深地经历上帝的赦免。圣经应许说「我们若认自己的罪，神是信实的，是公义的，必要赦免我们的罪」。

第三，找到触发点。是什么环境或情况让你特别容易犯这个罪？是深夜独处的时候？是跟某些朋友在一起的时候？是情绪低落的时候？认识你的模式，提前做好防备，尽量避开那些危险的环境。

第四，找一个问责伙伴。一个你信任的弟兄或姐妹，你们可以定期互相坦诚分享挣扎，互相祷告和鼓励。罪喜欢在黑暗中运作，当你把挣扎带到光明中，它的力量就减弱了。

第五，也是最关键的：靠圣灵的力量。真正的改变不是靠你的意志力和自我约束，而是靠圣灵在你里面的更新和工作。每天早上求圣灵帮助你，给你力量去抵挡试探。成圣是一个过程，不是一蹴而就的事。上帝看重的不是你的完美，而是你愿意一次次回到祂面前的心。进步可能很慢，但只要方向是对的，上帝就在微笑。
content_en:
First, you need to know you're not the only one struggling with this. The Apostle Paul — the spiritual giant who wrote nearly half the New Testament letters — honestly admitted, 'I do not do the good I want to do, but the evil I do not want to do — this I keep on doing' (Romans 7:19). If even Paul had this struggle, how much more will we! But this is absolutely not a reason to give up or despair.

First, don't lose hope. God's grace is sufficient for you. If you fall a hundred times, He'll pick you up a hundred and one times. His love for you isn't based on your performance but on Christ's completed redemption. Your sin doesn't make God stop loving you, just as a child falling doesn't make parents stop loving their child.

Second, be specific in confession. Don't just say generically, 'God, forgive my sins.' Honestly and specifically acknowledge what you did. This isn't because God doesn't know — it's because specific confession helps you truly face your problem and experience God's forgiveness more deeply. Scripture promises, 'If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins.'

Third, identify your triggers. What environments or situations make you especially vulnerable to this sin? Late at night alone? With certain friends? When emotionally low? Recognize your patterns, prepare in advance, and avoid those dangerous environments as much as possible.

Fourth, find an accountability partner. A trusted brother or sister you can regularly share struggles with honestly, praying for and encouraging each other. Sin loves to operate in darkness — when you bring struggles into the light, sin's power weakens.

Fifth, and most critically: rely on the Holy Spirit's power. Real change doesn't come from your willpower and self-discipline but from the Spirit's renewal and work within you. Every morning, ask the Holy Spirit for help and strength to resist temptation. Sanctification is a process, not an instant fix. God values not your perfection but your willingness to keep returning to Him. Progress may be slow, but as long as you're heading the right direction, God is smiling.

title_zh: 怎么知道上帝的旨意？
content_zh:
这是每个年轻基督徒都会问的问题——选什么专业？交什么朋友？未来做什么工作？要不要跟这个人谈恋爱？这些选择让人焦虑，我们都希望上帝能直接发一条短信告诉我们答案。但上帝的引导方式通常不是这样的。

首先要分清两种旨意。上帝的「显明旨意」是圣经里明确写的，比如爱人如己、不撒谎、追求圣洁、传福音等，这些不需要祷告求问，直接照着做就好。上帝的「隐秘旨意」是关于具体的人生选择，比如你该去哪个大学、做什么职业，这些需要我们用智慧去寻求。

对于隐秘旨意，这里有一些实用原则。第一，读圣经。上帝的旨意绝对不会违反圣经。如果一个选择明显违反圣经的教导，那就不是上帝的旨意。第二，祷告。雅各书说「你们中间若有缺少智慧的，应当求那厚赐与众人、也不斥责人的神，主就必赐给他」。把你的困惑带到上帝面前，求祂赐你智慧。第三，听建议。请教你信任的长辈、牧师、父母。圣经说「不先商议，所谋无效；谋士众多，所谋乃成」。第四，看环境。上帝会通过环境开门或关门来引导你，但要注意分辨，不是所有开着的门都应该走进去。第五，用理性。上帝给了你大脑，分析利弊、考虑恩赐和兴趣也是寻求旨意的一部分。第六，内心的平安。当你做对的决定时，圣灵会给你一种深层的平安，不是没有紧张，而是知道这是对的。

最重要的是不要焦虑。上帝是好牧人，祂比你更关心你的未来。即使你走了一段弯路，祂也有能力让万事互相效力。与其纠结于「找到完美的旨意」，不如专注于做一个忠心的门徒——在你现在的位置上爱上帝、爱人、忠心做事，上帝自然会引导你到下一步。
content_en:
This is a question every young Christian asks — what major to choose? What friends to make? What career to pursue? Should I date this person? These choices cause anxiety, and we all wish God would just send a text message with the answer. But God's guidance usually doesn't work that way.

First, distinguish two types of God's will. God's 'revealed will' is clearly stated in Scripture — love your neighbor, don't lie, pursue holiness, share the Gospel. These don't require prayer to figure out; just obey them. God's 'secret will' concerns specific life choices, like which college to attend or what career to pursue. These require wisdom to discern.

For the secret will, here are some practical principles. First, read the Bible. God's will absolutely never contradicts Scripture. If a choice clearly violates biblical teaching, it's not God's will. Second, pray. James says, 'If any of you lacks wisdom, you should ask God, who gives generously to all without finding fault, and it will be given to you.' Bring your confusion to God and ask for wisdom. Third, seek counsel. Ask trusted mentors, pastors, and parents. The Bible says, 'Plans fail for lack of counsel, but with many advisors they succeed.' Fourth, observe circumstances. God guides by opening and closing doors, but discern carefully — not every open door should be walked through. Fifth, use reason. God gave you a brain; analyzing pros and cons and considering your gifts and interests is part of seeking His will. Sixth, inner peace. When you make the right decision, the Holy Spirit gives a deep peace — not absence of nervousness, but knowing it's right.

Most importantly, don't be anxious. God is a good Shepherd who cares about your future more than you do. Even if you take a detour, He can make all things work together for good. Rather than obsessing over 'finding the perfect will,' focus on being a faithful disciple — love God, love people, be faithful where you are now, and God will naturally guide you to the next step.

title_zh: 感觉不到上帝怎么办？
title_en: What If I Can't Feel God?
content_zh:
几乎每个基督徒都经历过这种时期——明明信了上帝，但祷告的时候像是对着天花板说话，读经感觉像在读枯燥的课文，敬拜的时候心里毫无感动，感觉上帝很遥远，甚至怀疑祂是不是真的存在。这种经历叫做「灵里的干旱期」，是信仰旅程中非常正常的一部分，不要因此恐慌或者怀疑自己的信仰。

第一个重要的真相：信仰不是建立在感觉上的。感觉像天气一样会变化，今天阳光明媚明天可能乌云密布，但上帝的应许和祂对你的爱永远不会改变。你感觉不到祂，不代表祂不在。就像阴天看不到太阳，但太阳一直都在云层后面。上帝说过「我总不撇下你，也不丢弃你」，这个应许不取决于你的感受。

第二，诚实检查一下原因。有没有未认的罪在你和上帝之间筑了一道墙？是不是最近太忙了，长时间忽略了灵修和祷告？有时候是我们自己悄悄地拉远了与上帝的距离，就像不给朋友打电话然后抱怨朋友不找你一样。如果有罪，赶紧认罪悔改；如果是懒惰，重新建立灵修习惯。

第三，越是感觉不到，越要坚持属灵习惯。这就像在黑暗中走路，你不需要看到整条路才迈步，只需要看到脚前的一点光就够了。坚持祷告、坚持读经、坚持参加教会，即使毫无感觉。这种时候的坚持反而最能锻炼你的信心，因为你是凭信心而不是凭感觉在跟随上帝。

第四，不要一个人闷着。跟你信任的弟兄姐妹或者牧者分享你的感受，让他们为你祷告，陪你走过这段路。基督徒的生命不是独行侠的旅程。

第五，耐心等候上帝。有些时候上帝用安静来训练我们的信心，就像健身时肌肉需要承受压力才能变强。诗篇的作者也经历过同样的挣扎，他呼喊说「耶和华啊，你忘记我要到几时呢」，但最终他说「我倚靠你的慈爱，我的心因你的救恩快乐」。干旱的季节会过去的，坚持住，黎明就在前方。
content_en:
Almost every Christian goes through this — you believe in God, but prayer feels like talking to the ceiling, Bible reading feels like reading a dry textbook, worship stirs nothing in your heart, God seems far away, and you even wonder if He's really there. This experience is called a 'spiritual dry season,' a very normal part of the faith journey. Don't panic or doubt your faith because of it.

First important truth: faith isn't built on feelings. Feelings change like weather — sunny today, cloudy tomorrow — but God's promises and His love for you never change. Not feeling Him doesn't mean He's not there. Like not seeing the sun on a cloudy day, but the sun is always behind the clouds. God said, 'I will never leave you nor forsake you,' and this promise doesn't depend on your feelings.

Second, honestly check the reasons. Is there unconfessed sin building a wall between you and God? Have you been too busy lately, neglecting devotions and prayer for a long time? Sometimes we quietly create the distance ourselves — like not calling a friend and then complaining they never reach out. If there's sin, confess and repent quickly; if it's laziness, rebuild your devotional habits.

Third, the less you feel, the more you should maintain spiritual habits. It's like walking in darkness — you don't need to see the entire path to take a step, just enough light for your next footfall. Keep praying, keep reading Scripture, keep attending church, even when you feel nothing. Perseverance during these times actually strengthens your faith most, because you're following God by faith, not by feeling.

Fourth, don't bottle it up alone. Share your feelings with trusted brothers, sisters, or pastors. Let them pray for you and walk alongside you through this season. The Christian life isn't a lone ranger's journey.

Fifth, patiently wait on God. Sometimes God uses silence to train our faith, like muscles needing resistance to grow stronger. The psalmist experienced the same struggle, crying out, 'How long, LORD? Will you forget me forever?' Yet he concluded, 'I trust in your unfailing love; my heart rejoices in your salvation.' The dry season will pass. Hold on — dawn is just ahead.

title_zh: 父母不理解我的信仰
content_zh:
这可能是华人基督徒青少年最常见也最痛苦的挣扎之一。也许你的父母信佛教或民间信仰，拜祖先牌位，或者根本不信任何宗教觉得信仰是迷信。他们可能觉得你「被洗脑了」、「信了洋教」、「被教会的人骗了」。每次因为信仰跟父母起冲突，心里都特别难受。

第一，无论如何都要尊重父母。圣经命令我们孝敬父母（出埃及记二十章十二节），这条诫命没有附加条件说「只有父母是基督徒才需要孝敬」。不同意他们的信仰不等于可以不尊重他们、跟他们顶嘴或者偷偷摸摸。用更好的态度、更多的体贴来对待他们，让他们看到信仰给你带来的正面改变。

第二，用行动而不是嘴巴来说话。与其跟父母辩论神学，不如让他们亲眼看到你的改变。你比以前更孝顺了吗？更主动做家务了吗？学习更认真了吗？脾气变好了吗？行动比任何言语都更有说服力。很多父母最终接受甚至信主，就是因为看到了孩子生命真实的改变。

第三，保持耐心。你可能不能一夜之间改变父母的想法，这个过程可能需要很多年。但你可以每天为他们祷告，求上帝软化他们的心，打开他们的眼睛。上帝比你更爱你的父母，祂有祂的时间表。

第四，保持沟通而不是对抗。主动告诉父母你在教会做什么、学了什么，让他们了解你的信仰生活，减少他们的担忧和误解。如果他们不让你去教会，可以在家自己读经祷告，通过网络跟弟兄姐妹保持联系。不要因为信仰和父母决裂。

第五，寻求帮助。跟教会的牧师或青少年辅导谈谈你的处境，他们中很多人都有类似的经历，可以给你实用的智慧和鼓励。你不是一个人在面对这个挑战。

记住，上帝在你的家庭中也有祂美好的计划。也许祂把你放在这个家庭，就是为了让你成为祂在这个家中的光。不要灰心，继续用爱和耐心为你的家人祷告和见证。
content_en:
This might be one of the most common and painful struggles for Chinese Christian teenagers. Maybe your parents follow Buddhism or folk religion, worship ancestral tablets, or don't believe in any religion and consider faith superstition. They might think you've been 'brainwashed,' 'joined a foreign religion,' or 'been deceived by church people.' Every conflict with parents over faith hurts deeply.

First, respect your parents no matter what. The Bible commands us to honor our parents (Exodus 20:12), and this command doesn't come with the condition 'only if your parents are Christian.' Disagreeing with their beliefs doesn't mean you can disrespect them, talk back, or sneak around. Treat them with better attitudes and more thoughtfulness, letting them see the positive changes faith brings.

Second, let actions speak instead of words. Rather than debating theology with parents, let them see your transformation with their own eyes. Are you more respectful than before? More proactive with housework? More diligent in studies? Is your temper better? Actions are more persuasive than any words. Many parents eventually accept or even come to faith precisely because they witnessed genuine change in their children's lives.

Third, be patient. You may not change your parents' minds overnight — the process might take many years. But you can pray for them daily, asking God to soften their hearts and open their eyes. God loves your parents even more than you do, and He has His own timetable.

Fourth, communicate rather than confront. Proactively tell your parents what you do at church and what you're learning, helping them understand your faith life and reducing their worries and misunderstandings. If they won't let you attend church, read the Bible and pray at home, stay connected with fellow believers online. Don't let faith create a rift with your parents.

Fifth, seek help. Talk to your church pastor or youth leader about your situation — many of them have similar experiences and can offer practical wisdom and encouragement. You're not facing this challenge alone.

Remember, God has a beautiful plan for your family too. Perhaps He placed you in this family precisely so you could be His light in this home. Don't lose heart — keep praying and witnessing to your family with love and patience.

title_zh: 如何面对诱惑？
content_zh:
诱惑不是罪——这一点很重要，请记住！连耶稣自己都在旷野被魔鬼试探了四十天（马太福音四章），所以被诱惑不代表你灵命有问题。关键不是你有没有被试探，而是你怎么回应。诱惑可能来自很多方面：不合适的视频和图片、谎言、考试作弊、背后说人坏话、发脾气、沉迷游戏、贪婪嫉妒等等。

第一，认识你的弱点。你最容易在什么时候被诱惑？是无聊一个人待着的时候？是情绪低落生气的时候？是跟某些特定朋友在一起的时候？是深夜刷手机的时候？了解自己的弱点和容易犯罪的模式，才能提前做好防备。就像打仗要知道敌人从哪里进攻一样。

第二，远离试探的环境。「逃避」不是软弱，恰恰是智慧的表现。约瑟面对波提乏妻子的引诱时，他选择转身就跑（创世记三十九章）。如果深夜刷手机容易看到不该看的内容，那就把手机放到另一个房间。如果某些朋友总是带你做不好的事，那就减少跟他们的接触。不要高估自己抵抗诱惑的能力。

第三，用上帝的话语对抗。耶稣受试探的时候，每一次都用圣经的话来回应魔鬼。你也需要这个武器。记住一些关键经文，在诱惑来的时候大声说出来或者在心里默念。比如「你们所遇见的试探，无非是人所能受的。上帝是信实的，必不叫你们受试探过于所能受的」（哥林多前书十章十三节）。

第四，找人帮忙。不要一个人独自面对。告诉一个你信任的弟兄或姐妹你的挣扎，让他们为你祷告和问责。罪最喜欢在黑暗和秘密中生长，当你把挣扎带到光明中分享出来，它的力量就大大削弱了。

第五，依靠上帝的力量。靠自己的意志力去抵挡诱惑就像用纸盾牌挡子弹，迟早会失败。但圣灵住在你里面，祂有能力帮助你胜过试探。每天早上求圣灵充满你、保守你、赐你力量。

跌倒了不可怕，可怕的是躺着不起来。只要你愿意站起来，上帝的恩典永远够用。
content_en:
Temptation is not sin — this is important, so remember it! Even Jesus Himself was tempted by the devil for forty days in the wilderness (Matthew 4), so being tempted doesn't mean something's wrong with your spiritual life. What matters isn't whether you're tempted, but how you respond. Temptation comes in many forms: inappropriate videos and images, lying, cheating on exams, gossip, losing your temper, gaming addiction, greed, jealousy, and more.

First, know your weaknesses. When are you most vulnerable to temptation? When you're bored and alone? When you're emotionally low or angry? When you're with certain friends? When scrolling your phone late at night? Understanding your weaknesses and sin patterns allows you to prepare defenses in advance — like knowing where the enemy will attack in battle.

Second, flee from tempting environments. 'Running away' isn't weakness; it's actually wisdom. When Joseph faced Potiphar's wife's seduction, he turned and ran (Genesis 39). If late-night phone scrolling exposes you to harmful content, put your phone in another room. If certain friends always lead you astray, reduce contact with them. Don't overestimate your ability to resist temptation.

Third, fight with God's Word. Every time Jesus was tempted, He responded with Scripture. You need this weapon too. Memorize key verses and speak them aloud or recite them silently when temptation strikes. For example: 'No temptation has overtaken you except what is common to mankind. God is faithful; He will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear' (1 Corinthians 10:13).

Fourth, get help. Don't face this alone. Tell a trusted brother or sister about your struggles and let them pray for you and hold you accountable. Sin loves to grow in darkness and secrecy — when you bring struggles into the light and share them, sin's power is greatly weakened.

Fifth, rely on God's strength. Resisting temptation with your own willpower is like blocking bullets with a paper shield — you'll eventually fail. But the Holy Spirit lives within you and has the power to help you overcome. Every morning, ask the Spirit to fill you, protect you, and give you strength.

Falling isn't the disaster — staying down is. As long as you're willing to get back up, God's grace is always sufficient.

title_zh: 什么是门徒？
content_zh:
「门徒」这个词的意思就是「学生」或者「跟随者」。在圣经的时代，做门徒可不是坐在教室里听课那么简单。门徒要跟老师一起生活、一起吃饭、一起走路、一起工作，学习老师说的每一句话，模仿老师做的每一件事。门徒的目标不只是知道老师知道的，而是要成为老师那样的人。

做耶稣的门徒也是同样的道理。不是只在周日早上去教会坐一坐、听一听就完事了，而是全天候地跟随耶稣、学习耶稣、活出耶稣的样式。你在学校怎么对待同学是门徒训练，你在家怎么跟父母说话是门徒训练，你一个人的时候怎么使用时间也是门徒训练。信仰不是生活的一部分，信仰就是你的整个生活。

耶稣对门徒的要求非常直接：「若有人要跟从我，就当舍己，天天背起他的十字架来跟从我」（路加福音九章二十三节）。这意味着什么呢？「舍己」就是不再以自己为中心，而是把耶稣放在第一位。当你的欲望跟上帝的旨意冲突时，选择上帝的旨意。「天天背十字架」意味着每天都要面对为信仰付出代价的准备，可能是被嘲笑、被误解、放弃一些自己想要的东西。

但做门徒不只是牺牲和辛苦。耶稣也说「我来了，是要叫人得生命，并且得的更丰盛」。跟随耶稣，你会发现生命有了真正的意义和方向，你不再为讨好每一个人而活，你有了坚实的身份认同——你是上帝的孩子。这种自由和喜乐是世界给不了的。

做门徒不是基督徒的「额外学分」或者「进阶课程」——这是每一个基督徒的基本身份。你不是在「考虑要不要做门徒」，当你接受耶稣的那一刻，你已经被呼召成为门徒了！问题不是「要不要做」，而是「怎么做得更好」。从今天开始，在每个小事上忠心跟随祂。
content_en:
The word 'disciple' means 'student' or 'follower.' In biblical times, being a disciple wasn't as simple as sitting in a classroom listening to lectures. Disciples lived with their teacher, ate together, walked together, worked together, learned every word the teacher spoke, and imitated everything the teacher did. A disciple's goal wasn't just knowing what the teacher knew, but becoming like the teacher.

Being Jesus' disciple works the same way. It's not just showing up at church on Sunday morning, sitting for a bit, and calling it done. It's following Jesus around the clock — learning from Him and living like Him. How you treat classmates at school is discipleship training. How you talk to your parents at home is discipleship training. How you spend time when you're alone is discipleship training. Faith isn't a part of life; faith IS your entire life.

Jesus' requirement for disciples is very direct: 'Whoever wants to be my disciple must deny themselves and take up their cross daily and follow me' (Luke 9:23). What does this mean? 'Deny yourself' means no longer being self-centered but putting Jesus first. When your desires conflict with God's will, choose God's will. 'Take up your cross daily' means being prepared every day to pay a price for faith — perhaps being mocked, misunderstood, or giving up things you want.

But discipleship isn't only sacrifice and hardship. Jesus also said, 'I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full.' Following Jesus, you'll discover life has real meaning and direction. You no longer live to please everyone. You have a solid identity — you're God's child. This freedom and joy is something the world cannot give.

Being a disciple isn't 'extra credit' or an 'advanced course' for Christians — it's every Christian's basic identity. You're not 'considering whether to become a disciple.' The moment you accepted Jesus, you were called to be one! The question isn't 'should I?' but 'how can I do it better?' Starting today, faithfully follow Him in every small thing.

title_zh: 属灵习惯的建立
content_zh:
属灵生命就像身体一样需要规律的锻炼和营养。你不会期望一天不吃饭还能精力充沛地跑步，属灵生命也是一样。如果你想在信仰上成长，就需要建立一些核心的属灵习惯，就像运动员每天训练一样。

第一，每日灵修。每天花十五到二十分钟读经和祷告。早上起来或者晚上睡前都可以，关键是找一个固定的时间和安静的地方，让这成为你每天的「约会时间」。可以从新约的马可福音或者约翰福音开始读，不需要读很多，慢慢消化比囫囵吞枣更有益处。

第二，持续祷告。祷告不只是饭前说几句话，而是随时随地跟上帝对话的习惯。开心的时候感谢祂，遇到困难的时候求助祂，犯错的时候向祂认罪，看到美好事物的时候赞美祂。祷告让你跟上帝的关系保持活泼和亲密。

第三，参加敬拜。每个主日参加教会崇拜，这不是一项「任务」或者「打卡」，而是跟上帝的大家庭一起庆祝、一起感恩、一起领受上帝话语的喜乐时光。

第四，加入团契。找一个小组或者青少年团契，跟其他基督徒定期见面、分享生活、一起祷告、彼此鼓励。信仰不是独行侠的旅程，你需要同路人。

第五，参与服事。用上帝给你的恩赐和才能去帮助别人、祝福教会。开始不需要很大的事，也许就是帮教会摆椅子、做投影片、带领破冰游戏。在服事中你会经历到给予的喜乐，也会发现自己的恩赐。

建立这些习惯的关键是：从小处开始，坚持下去。不要一开始就设定太高的目标，比如每天读十章圣经祷告一小时，这样很快就会放弃。从五分钟开始也可以，关键是每天都做。习惯不是一天养成的，你会有偷懒的时候，没关系，不要因此放弃，第二天重新开始就好。给自己恩典，就像上帝给你恩典一样。记住，属灵习惯的目的不是「赚取分数」，而是培养你跟上帝之间活泼的关系。
content_en:
Your spiritual life, like your body, needs regular exercise and nutrition. You wouldn't expect to run energetically without eating all day — your spiritual life works the same way. If you want to grow in faith, you need to establish core spiritual habits, just like an athlete trains daily.

First, daily devotions. Spend fifteen to twenty minutes each day reading Scripture and praying. Morning or bedtime both work — the key is finding a consistent time and quiet place, making it your daily 'date time.' Start with Mark or John in the New Testament. You don't need to read a lot; slow digestion is more beneficial than rushing through.

Second, continuous prayer. Prayer isn't just saying a few words before meals — it's the habit of conversing with God anytime, anywhere. Thank Him when you're happy, ask for help in difficulties, confess when you mess up, praise Him when you see beautiful things. Prayer keeps your relationship with God vibrant and intimate.

Third, attend worship. Join church services every Sunday — not as a 'task' or 'checking in,' but as joyful time celebrating with God's family, giving thanks together, and receiving God's Word together.

Fourth, join fellowship. Find a small group or youth fellowship to regularly meet with other Christians, share life, pray together, and encourage one another. Faith isn't a lone ranger's journey; you need companions.

Fifth, participate in service. Use the gifts and talents God gave you to help others and bless the church. Start small — maybe setting up chairs, running slides, or leading icebreaker games. Through serving, you'll experience the joy of giving and discover your gifts.

The key to building these habits: start small, stay consistent. Don't set overly ambitious goals at first, like reading ten chapters daily and praying for an hour — you'll give up quickly. Starting with five minutes is fine; the key is doing it every day. Habits aren't built overnight. You'll have lazy days — that's okay. Don't quit because of it; just restart the next day. Give yourself grace, just as God gives you grace. Remember, the purpose of spiritual habits isn't 'earning points' but cultivating a vibrant relationship with God.

title_zh: 如何在小组中成长
content_zh:
小组不只是一个额外的活动或者社交聚会——它是你属灵成长最重要的环境之一。很多人觉得只要自己一个人读经祷告就够了，但上帝设计的信仰生活是群体性的。圣经说「铁磨铁，磨出刃来；朋友相感，也是如此」。你需要被磨练，也需要磨练别人。

在小组里，你可以做几件在其他地方做不到的事。第一，真实地分享。你不需要假装自己很属灵、很完美。小组是一个安全的空间，你可以分享你的挣扎、困惑、软弱和失败。当你发现别人也有类似的挣扎时，你会感到不再孤单。这才是真正的团契——不是表面的客气，而是生命深处的连接。

第二，彼此学习。每个人的生命经历不同，对圣经的理解也不同。听别人分享他们的见解和经历，你会发现上帝在不同人的生命中有不同但同样美好的作为。一个人读经可能会有盲点，但在小组讨论中往往能看到你自己看不到的角度。

第三，互相代祷。当你知道有人在为你的考试、家庭、挣扎祷告时，那种被关心被支持的感觉是很不一样的。代祷不只是帮助被祷告的人，也帮助祷告的人学习爱别人。

第四，互相问责。帮助彼此在信仰上保持忠心。当你知道下周聚会时弟兄姐妹会问你这周灵修情况，你就更有动力去做。这不是律法主义，而是爱的督促。

第五，一起服事。小组可以一起做一些服事项目，比如探访老人、帮助社区、一起传福音。在合作中你会学到更多关于合一和彼此配搭的功课。

怎么做一个好的小组成员呢？准时到场，积极参与讨论而不是只做沉默的观众，保守别人分享的隐私不到处传播，主动关心组员的生活和需要，愿意承担一些责任比如轮流带领祷告或准备茶点。

小组不完美——里面的人都是罪人，会有摩擦、有误解、有让你不舒服的时候。但就是在这种不完美的关系中，你学会了真正的爱和被爱、饶恕和被饶恕。这比舒适但肤浅的关系宝贵太多了。
content_en:
Small group isn't just an extra activity or social gathering — it's one of the most important environments for your spiritual growth. Many people think personal Bible reading and prayer is enough, but God designed the faith life to be communal. The Bible says, 'As iron sharpens iron, so one person sharpens another.' You need to be sharpened, and you need to sharpen others.

In small group, you can do things you can't do elsewhere. First, share authentically. You don't need to pretend you're super spiritual or perfect. Small group is a safe space where you can share your struggles, confusion, weakness, and failures. When you discover others have similar struggles, you'll feel less alone. This is real fellowship — not surface politeness, but deep life-to-life connection.

Second, learn from each other. Everyone's life experiences differ, as do their understandings of Scripture. Hearing others share their insights and experiences reveals how God works differently but equally beautifully in each person's life. Reading alone may create blind spots, but group discussion often reveals angles you couldn't see yourself.

Third, pray for each other. Knowing someone is praying for your exams, family, and struggles creates a unique feeling of being cared for and supported. Intercession doesn't just help the person being prayed for — it helps the one praying learn to love others.

Fourth, hold each other accountable. Help one another stay faithful in their walk. Knowing your brothers and sisters will ask about your devotional life at next week's meeting motivates you. This isn't legalism — it's love's encouragement.

Fifth, serve together. Groups can take on service projects together — visiting the elderly, helping the community, evangelizing together. Through collaboration, you'll learn valuable lessons about unity and working together.

How to be a good group member? Show up on time, actively participate in discussion rather than being a silent spectator, keep others' shared stories confidential, proactively care about members' lives and needs, and be willing to take on responsibilities like leading prayer or preparing snacks.

Small groups aren't perfect — everyone in them is a sinner, so there'll be friction, misunderstandings, and uncomfortable moments. But it's precisely in these imperfect relationships that you learn true love and being loved, forgiveness and being forgiven. This is infinitely more valuable than comfortable but shallow relationships.
discussion_questions: 你在小组中最喜欢什么？最不喜欢什么？ What do you like most about small group? Least?
你觉得'真实地分享'为什么这么难？ Why do you think 'sharing authentically' is so hard?
一个好的小组应该是什么样子的？ What should a good small group look like?

title_zh: 服事他人
content_zh:
耶稣——创造宇宙万物的王——在最后的晚餐上却蹲下来，拿起毛巾和水盆，亲手给门徒们洗脚（约翰福音十三章）。在那个时代，洗脚是最卑微的仆人才做的工作。宇宙的主宰做了仆人的活，如果连祂都愿意这样服事，我们还有什么理由觉得自己太重要、太忙、太优秀而不去服事别人呢？

服事不是什么「高大上」的事情，不需要你有超级能力或者特殊恩赐才能开始。服事就在你每天的日常生活中：帮同学解答一道不会的题目，主动打扫家里的卫生，在教会帮忙搬桌椅、做清洁，花时间陪一个孤独的人聊天让他知道有人在乎他，默默为朋友的困难祷告，把零用钱分享给有需要的人。这些看起来微不足道的小事，在上帝眼中都是宝贵的服事。

服事的关键不在于你做了什么大事，而在于你的心态。你是出于爱和感恩去做，还是为了被人看到、被人表扬？真正的服事是不求回报的。当没有人注意、没有人鼓掌的时候你还愿意做，那才是真正的服事。

耶稣说了一句让人震撼的话：「这些事你们既做在我这弟兄中一个最小的身上，就是做在我身上了」（马太福音二十五章四十节）。当你帮助那个被欺负的同学、关心那个没有朋友的人、陪伴那个难过的弟兄姐妹时，你其实是在服事耶稣本人！

每个人都有上帝赐的独特恩赐。也许你擅长音乐，可以在敬拜中服事；也许你擅长写作，可以帮教会写文章；也许你运动很棒，可以组织体育活动；也许你懂科技，可以帮忙做网站或投影；也许你会做饭，可以在聚会时准备食物。找到你的恩赐，然后慷慨地用它来祝福别人。

你不需要等到「长大」或者「灵命成熟」才开始服事。耶稣的门徒很多都是年轻人，大卫击败歌利亚的时候可能才十几岁。现在就开始吧！从身边最小的事做起，你会发现：当你祝福别人的时候，你自己也被深深祝福了。服事不是负担，而是特权和喜乐。
content_en:
Jesus — the King who created the entire universe — at the Last Supper knelt down, took a towel and basin, and personally washed His disciples' feet (John 13). In that era, foot-washing was the lowliest servant's job. The Lord of the universe did a servant's work. If even He was willing to serve this way, what reason do we have to think we're too important, too busy, or too good to serve others?

Service isn't some grand, extraordinary thing requiring superpowers or special gifts to begin. Service exists in your everyday life: helping a classmate solve a problem they can't figure out, proactively cleaning the house, helping set up chairs and clean at church, spending time talking with a lonely person so they know someone cares, quietly praying for a friend's difficulties, sharing your allowance with someone in need. These seemingly insignificant acts are all precious service in God's eyes.

The key to service isn't what grand things you accomplish but your heart's attitude. Are you doing it out of love and gratitude, or to be seen and praised? True service expects nothing in return. When no one notices and no one applauds but you're still willing to do it — that's real service.

Jesus said something stunning: 'Whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me' (Matthew 25:40). When you help the bullied classmate, care for the friendless person, or comfort a hurting brother or sister, you're actually serving Jesus Himself!

Everyone has unique gifts from God. Maybe you're musically gifted and can serve in worship; maybe you're a good writer and can write for the church; maybe you excel at sports and can organize activities; maybe you're tech-savvy and can help with websites or presentations; maybe you cook well and can prepare food for gatherings. Find your gifts and generously use them to bless others.

You don't need to wait until you're 'grown up' or 'spiritually mature' to start serving. Many of Jesus' disciples were young people, and David was probably just a teenager when he defeated Goliath. Start now! Begin with the smallest things around you, and you'll discover: when you bless others, you yourself are deeply blessed. Service isn't a burden — it's a privilege and joy.
discussion_questions: 你最近为别人做过什么服事的事？ What's something you've done recently to serve someone?
你觉得自己有什么恩赐可以用来服事？ What gifts do you have that you could use to serve?
服事别人和'被别人利用'有什么区别？ What's the difference between serving others and being taken advantage of?

title_zh: 分享你的信仰
content_zh:
分享信仰（传福音）可能是很多基督徒觉得最难的事。'如果被拒绝怎么办？''如果说错了怎么办？''我又不是牧师。'但记住：恐惧不是来自上帝的，而你有最好的消息——永生、赦免、盼望！

克服恐惧的真理：
你不需要是神学家才能分享。最有力的见证就是你自己的故事。
结果不是你的责任——你的工作是撒种，圣灵负责让种子发芽。
拒绝福音不是拒绝你——他们拒绝的是耶稣，不要往心里去。

如何分享你的见证：
你的个人见证通常有三个部分：信主前（你的生活、挣扎）、信主时（怎么遇见基督、什么打动了你）、信主后（生命有了什么改变）。即使从小在基督徒家庭长大，你的见证也可以是信仰从「父母的」变成「我自己的」的过程。保持真实，不要夸张；聚焦在基督做了什么；练习用2-3分钟讲完。

实用技巧：
1）先建立关系——人们不在乎你知道多少，直到他们知道你有多在乎。
2）自然地分享——不需要硬塞，在聊天中自然提到。用对方能理解的语言，避免太多教会术语。
3）学会倾听——了解对方的想法和需要，然后用福音来回应。
4）随时预备——'常作准备，好回答每一个问你们心中盼望缘由的人'（彼得前书3:15）。
5）从小事开始——邀请朋友参加教会活动、在困难时提到祷告。
6）靠圣灵——改变人心是上帝的工作，不是你的。求圣灵给你机会、话语和勇气。

传福音最大的秘诀：真诚的爱。当人们感受到你真的关心他们时，他们更愿意听。失败了又怎样？天不会塌。但如果成功了呢？永恒都会不同！
content_en:
Sharing your faith (evangelism) might feel like the hardest thing for many Christians. 'What if I get rejected?' 'What if I say the wrong thing?' 'I'm not a pastor.' But remember: fear doesn't come from God, and you have the best news — eternal life, forgiveness, hope!

Truths to overcome fear:
You don't need to be a theologian. The most powerful testimony is YOUR story.
The outcome isn't your responsibility — you plant seeds; the Spirit makes them grow.
Rejecting the Gospel isn't rejecting you — they're rejecting Jesus, not you personally.

How to share your testimony:
A good testimony has three parts: before Christ (your life, struggles), meeting Christ (how you encountered Him, what moved you), after Christ (how life has changed). Even if you grew up in a Christian family, your testimony can be about faith becoming 'my own' rather than 'my parents'.' Stay authentic, don't exaggerate; focus on what Christ did; practice telling it in 2-3 minutes.

Practical tips:
1) Build relationships first — people don't care how much you know until they know how much you care.
2) Share naturally — don't force it. Bring it up in conversation. Use language your audience understands, avoid church jargon.
3) Learn to listen — understand what the other person thinks and needs, then connect the Gospel to that.
4) Always be ready — 'Always be prepared to give an answer to everyone who asks you to give the reason for the hope that you have' (1 Peter 3:15).
5) Start small — invite friends to church events, mention prayer during tough times.
6) Rely on the Spirit — changing hearts is God's job, not yours. Ask for opportunities, words, and courage.

The biggest secret of evangelism: genuine love. When people feel you truly care, they're more willing to listen. What if you fail? The world won't end. But what if you succeed? Eternity will be different!
discussion_questions: 你有没有跟别人分享过你的信仰？什么感觉？ Have you ever shared your faith with someone? How did it feel?
如果你有30秒来分享福音，你会说什么？ If you had 30 seconds to share the Gospel, what would you say?
传福音时最让你害怕的是什么？怎么克服？ What scares you most about evangelism? How can you overcome it?
传福音时你最怕什么？这些恐惧合理吗？ What do you fear most about evangelism? Are these fears reasonable?
'真诚的爱'在传福音中具体是什么样子的？ What does 'genuine love' look like practically in evangelism?
你有没有因为不传福音而后悔过？分享一下。 Have you ever regretted not sharing the Gospel? Share about it.
你能用三句话概括你的信仰见证吗？ Can you summarize your testimony in three sentences?
分享见证时你最担心什么？ What worries you most about sharing your testimony?

title_zh: 三位一体简单解释
content_zh:
三位一体听起来很复杂，但其实是基督教最美丽的真理之一。上帝是一位神，但祂同时以三个位格存在：圣父、圣子（耶稣）、圣灵。不是三个神，也不是一个神在演三个角色，而是一个神性、三个位格同时存在的奥秘。

想象一下阳光：太阳本身、光线、温暖——不可分割，却又可以分辨。不过所有的比喻都不完美，因为三位一体超越了我们日常的经验。特别要注意：水的三种状态（冰、水、蒸汽）这个常见比喻其实是错误的，因为水在同一时间只能是一种状态，但三位一体的三个位格是同时存在的。

三个位格各有什么角色？ 圣父是创造者和计划者，圣子耶稣是救赎者和道路，圣灵是安慰者和引导者。他们同等重要，本质相同，但功能不同。圣父创造了我们，圣子拯救了我们，圣灵住在我们里面。

当你祷告时， 你向圣父祷告，因着耶稣的名，靠着圣灵的帮助——三个位格都参与在你和上帝的关系中。

为什么这很重要？ 因为这告诉我们上帝的本质就是关系和爱。三位一体内部有完美的爱的交流，我们也被邀请参与这种爱的关系中。上帝理解关系、理解团体，因为祂自己就是完美的关系。认识三位一体不只是知识，更是认识那位深爱你的上帝是怎样的一位神。
content_en:
The Trinity sounds complicated, but it's actually one of Christianity's most beautiful truths. God is one God, but He exists simultaneously as three persons: Father, Son (Jesus), and Holy Spirit. Not three gods, nor one God playing three roles, but one divine nature in three persons existing at the same time — a profound mystery.

Think of sunlight: the sun itself, the light rays, the warmth — inseparable yet distinguishable. Though all analogies are imperfect, because the Trinity transcends our everyday experience. One common but misleading analogy is water's three states (ice, liquid, steam) — this actually teaches the heresy of modalism, since water can only be in one state at a time, while the three persons of the Trinity exist simultaneously.

What are their roles? The Father is the Creator and Planner, Jesus the Son is the Redeemer and Way, the Holy Spirit is the Comforter and Guide. They're equally important, same essence, but different functions. The Father created us, the Son saved us, the Spirit lives in us.

When you pray, you pray to the Father, in Jesus' name, with the Spirit's help — all three persons are involved in your relationship with God.

Why does this matter? Because it tells us that God's very essence is relationship and love. Within the Trinity, there's perfect loving communion, and we're invited into this loving relationship too. God understands relationships and community because He IS perfect relationship. Knowing the Trinity isn't just theology — it's knowing what kind of God deeply loves you.

三位一体对你个人的信仰生活有什么意义？ What does the Trinity mean for your personal faith life?
你觉得为什么上帝要以三位一体的方式存在？ Why do you think God exists as Trinity?
用你自己的话解释三位一体。How would you explain the Trinity in your own words?
知道上帝是关系性的对你的祷告生活有什么影响？How does knowing God is relational affect your prayer life?
为什么三位一体不是'三个神'？Why isn't the Trinity 'three gods'?

title_zh: 圣经是什么？
content_zh:
圣经不是一本书，而是一整个图书馆！它包含六十六本书，由大约四十位不同的作者在将近一千五百年的时间里写成。这些作者背景各异——有国王、牧羊人、渔夫、税吏、医生、先知——但神奇的是，他们写出的内容竟然有一个完美统一的主题：上帝拯救人类的计划。这本身就是一个超自然的奇迹。

圣经分为旧约和新约两大部分。旧约有三十九本书，主要讲述上帝创造世界、呼召以色列民族、与他们立约的故事，同时预言一位救世主即将到来。新约有二十七本书，记载了耶稣的降生、教导、死亡、复活，以及早期教会的建立和使徒们的书信。从创世记到启示录，整本圣经都指向一个人：耶稣基督。祂是圣经的中心。

圣经是「神所默示的」（提摩太后书三章十六节），这是什么意思呢？意思是圣灵引导人类作者写下了上帝想要告诉我们的话。这不是机械式的听写，好像上帝念一句作者写一句，而是上帝通过每个作者独特的个性、背景、教育程度和写作风格来传达真理。所以你会发现保罗的书信和约翰的书信风格完全不同，但传达的都是上帝的真理。

圣经不是科学教科书，也不是历史百科全书。它的首要目的不是教你化学公式或者列出详细的年表，而是上帝对人类的启示。它要告诉我们四件最重要的事：上帝是谁、我们是谁、罪的问题有多严重、救恩的道路在哪里。

圣经也是经得起考验的。考古学不断发现与圣经记载吻合的证据，圣经手抄本的数量和准确性远超任何其他古代文献。两千年来，无数人试图摧毁圣经，但它依然是世界上被翻译最多、印刷最多、阅读最多的书。

当我们带着信心和祷告的心读圣经时，圣灵会亲自向我们说话，光照我们的心，改变我们的生命。圣经不是死的文字，而是活泼的、有功效的上帝之道。
content_en:
The Bible isn't one book — it's an entire library! It contains sixty-six books, written by about forty different authors over nearly fifteen hundred years. These authors came from vastly different backgrounds — kings, shepherds, fishermen, tax collectors, doctors, prophets — yet amazingly, their writings share one perfectly unified theme: God's plan to save humanity. This itself is a supernatural miracle.

The Bible is divided into two major sections: Old Testament and New Testament. The Old Testament has thirty-nine books, primarily telling the story of God creating the world, calling the nation of Israel, and making covenants with them, while prophesying a coming Savior. The New Testament has twenty-seven books, recording Jesus' birth, teaching, death, resurrection, and the early church's establishment along with the apostles' letters. From Genesis to Revelation, the entire Bible points to one person: Jesus Christ. He is the Bible's center.

The Bible is 'God-breathed' (2 Timothy 3:16) — what does this mean? It means the Holy Spirit guided human authors to write what God wanted to communicate to us. This wasn't mechanical dictation where God spoke and the author simply transcribed. Rather, God communicated truth through each author's unique personality, background, education level, and writing style. So you'll notice Paul's letters and John's letters have completely different styles, yet both convey God's truth.

The Bible isn't a science textbook or history encyclopedia. Its primary purpose isn't teaching chemistry formulas or providing detailed timelines. It's God's revelation to humanity, telling us four crucial things: who God is, who we are, how serious the sin problem is, and where the path of salvation lies.

The Bible also withstands scrutiny. Archaeology continuously discovers evidence aligning with biblical records, and the quantity and accuracy of biblical manuscripts far exceeds any other ancient literature. For two thousand years, countless people have tried to destroy the Bible, yet it remains the world's most translated, most printed, and most read book.

When we read the Bible with faith and prayer, the Holy Spirit personally speaks to us, illuminates our hearts, and transforms our lives. The Bible isn't dead letters but the living, active Word of God.

圣经和其他宗教经典有什么不同？ How is the Bible different from other religious texts?
你觉得为什么上帝选择用书面文字来启示自己？ Why do you think God chose to reveal Himself through written words?

title_zh: 教会为什么重要？
content_zh:
很多人觉得「我可以在家自己信上帝，干嘛要去教会？」这就好比说「我可以在家自己踢球，干嘛要加入球队？」当然，你可以一个人踢球，但你永远学不会配合、永远体验不到团队胜利的喜悦、永远没有队友在你受伤时扶你一把。信仰不是个人独奏，而是交响乐团的合作——每个人演奏不同的乐器，合在一起才能奏出美妙的音乐。

圣经用「基督的身体」来形容教会，我们每个人都是其中的肢体（哥林多前书十二章二十七节）。手不能对脚说「我不需要你」，眼睛不能对耳朵说「我用不着你」。同样，基督徒也不能孤立地成长。我们被设计成需要彼此的。

在教会里，你可以做很多一个人做不到的事：一起敬拜赞美上帝，那种众人同声歌唱的感动是一个人在家无法体验的；彼此鼓励和代祷，在你软弱跌倒的时候有人扶你一把；一起学习圣经，从不同角度理解上帝的话语；使用恩赐互相服事，在给予中学会爱；接受牧者的教导、牧养和关怀，在属灵上不断成长。

当然，教会不完美。里面的人都是罪人——包括牧师。会有八卦、有误解、有让你失望的事情。但这恰恰是我们需要教会的原因。在不完美的群体中学习爱和被爱、学习饶恕和被饶恕、学习忍耐和谦卑，这才是真正的属灵成长。如果你只愿意跟「完美的人」在一起，那你永远找不到教会——因为你自己走进去的那一刻，它就不完美了。

不去教会的基督徒就像离开火堆的炭——单独一块炭很快就会熄灭，但放在一起就能持续燃烧发光。找一个忠于圣经教导、充满爱心和活力的教会，委身其中，参与服事，建立关系。你会发现教会是上帝给你最好的礼物之一。不是因为教会完美，而是因为在不完美中，上帝做了最美好的工作。
content_en:
Many people think, 'I can believe in God at home — why go to church?' That's like saying, 'I can kick a ball at home — why join a team?' Sure, you can play alone, but you'll never learn teamwork, never experience the joy of winning together, never have a teammate to help you up when you're hurt. Faith isn't a solo performance — it's a symphony orchestra collaboration where everyone plays different instruments, creating beautiful music only together.

The Bible describes the church as 'the body of Christ,' with each of us as members (1 Corinthians 12:27). The hand can't say to the foot, 'I don't need you.' The eye can't say to the ear, 'I have no use for you.' Likewise, Christians can't grow in isolation. We were designed to need each other.

In church, you can do many things impossible alone: worship and praise God together — the feeling of singing in unison can't be replicated at home; encourage and pray for each other — having someone lift you up when you're weak and fallen; study the Bible together — understanding God's Word from different perspectives; serve one another using your gifts — learning to love through giving; receive pastoral teaching, shepherding, and care — growing spiritually.

Of course, church isn't perfect. Everyone there is a sinner — including the pastor. There'll be gossip, misunderstandings, and disappointments. But that's precisely why we need church. Learning to love and be loved in an imperfect community, learning to forgive and be forgiven, learning patience and humility — that's real spiritual growth. If you only want to be around 'perfect people,' you'll never find a church — because the moment you walk in, it's no longer perfect.

A Christian without church is like a coal separated from the fire — a single coal quickly goes cold, but together they keep burning bright. Find a Bible-faithful, loving, vibrant church, commit to it, participate in service, and build relationships. You'll discover church is one of God's best gifts to you. Not because church is perfect, but because in imperfection, God does His most beautiful work.

如果朋友说"教会里都是伪君子"，你会怎么回应？ If a friend says "church is full of hypocrites," how would you respond?

title_zh: 洗礼和圣餐
content_zh:
洗礼和圣餐是上帝赐给教会的两个「圣礼」——用看得见的方式来表达看不见的恩典，就像拥抱是用看得见的动作表达看不见的爱一样。

先说洗礼。洗礼是你信仰的公开宣告，当你受洗的时候，你是在众人面前宣告「我相信耶稣基督，我决定一生跟随祂」。水代表洗净和更新，浸入水中象征你与基督同死——旧的你被埋葬了，从水中起来象征你与基督同复活——一个全新的你诞生了（罗马书六章四节）。洗礼是一个美丽的画面，宣告你的旧生命已经过去，新生命已经开始。

需要特别说明的是，洗礼不是得救的条件，而是得救的表达和见证。就像结婚戒指不能让你结婚，但它向全世界宣告你已经结婚了。你不是因为受洗才成为基督徒，而是因为你已经相信了基督才去受洗。如果你已经信主但还没有受洗，勇敢地迈出这一步吧，这是对上帝信心的美好回应。

再说圣餐，也叫主餐或擘饼。这是耶稣在被钉十字架前的最后晚餐上设立的。饼代表祂为我们破碎的身体，杯中的葡萄汁代表祂为我们流出的宝血。每次我们吃饼喝杯的时候，我们在做三件事：回忆过去——记念耶稣在十字架上为我们所做的牺牲；活在当下——在信心中重新领受上帝的恩典，检视自己的生命；期待未来——预尝天国筵席的喜乐，盼望基督再来。

圣餐不是魔法仪式，饼和杯也没有神奇的力量。它是信心的行动和团契的表达——我们一起领受，表明我们同属一个身体，共享一位救主。

这两个圣礼提醒我们一个重要的真理：信仰不只是内心的事，也需要外在可见的见证。上帝用水、饼、杯这些看得见摸得着的东西来帮助我们理解和经历祂看不见的恩典。它们是上帝恩典的可见标志，帮助我们用整个人——包括我们的身体——来回应上帝的爱和敬拜祂。
content_en:
Baptism and Communion are two 'sacraments' God gave the church — expressing invisible grace in visible ways, just as a hug expresses invisible love through a visible action.

Let's start with baptism. Baptism is a public declaration of your faith. When you're baptized, you're proclaiming before everyone, 'I believe in Jesus Christ and have decided to follow Him for life.' Water represents cleansing and renewal. Going under the water symbolizes dying with Christ — the old you is buried. Rising from the water symbolizes rising with Christ — a brand new you is born (Romans 6:4). Baptism is a beautiful picture declaring your old life has passed away and new life has begun.

It's important to clarify: baptism isn't a requirement for salvation but an expression and testimony of it. Like a wedding ring doesn't make you married, but announces to the world that you are. You don't become a Christian because you're baptized; you get baptized because you already believe in Christ. If you've believed but haven't been baptized, take that courageous step — it's a beautiful response of faith to God.

Now for Communion, also called the Lord's Supper or breaking of bread. Jesus established this at the Last Supper before His crucifixion. The bread represents His body broken for us; the cup of grape juice represents His precious blood shed for us. Each time we eat the bread and drink the cup, we're doing three things: remembering the past — commemorating Jesus' sacrifice on the cross for us; living in the present — receiving God's grace anew in faith and examining our lives; anticipating the future — getting a foretaste of heaven's feast and longing for Christ's return.

Communion isn't a magic ritual, and the bread and cup don't have mystical power. It's an act of faith and expression of fellowship — receiving together demonstrates we belong to one body and share one Savior.

These two sacraments remind us of an important truth: faith isn't just an internal matter; it also needs visible, external witness. God uses tangible things like water, bread, and cup to help us understand and experience His invisible grace. They're visible signs of God's grace, helping us respond to God's love and worship Him with our whole person — including our bodies.

title_zh: 如何读圣经（方法论）
content_zh:
读圣经不是像读小说那样从头到尾快速翻完就好，圣经需要细心地、有方法地去读。这里介绍一个经典又实用的方法叫做「归纳法查经」——包括观察、解释、应用三个步骤。掌握了这个方法，你读经就不再漫无目的了。

第一步是观察，就是仔细阅读经文，问自己「这段经文到底说了什么？」注意几个关键要素：有哪些关键词？有没有重复出现的字词？有没有对比或转折？出现了什么人物？在什么地点和时间发生？作者的语气是什么？别急着下结论或跳到应用，先像侦探一样收集所有的线索和信息。好的观察是正确理解的基础。

第二步是解释，就是问「这段经文的原意是什么？作者到底想表达什么？」这一步需要考虑几个重要因素：历史背景——当时发生了什么事；文化背景——那个时代的人怎么理解这些话；上下文——前后的经文在讲什么；文体——是诗歌、叙述、书信、预言还是其他类型。最核心的原则是「以经解经」，用圣经其他部分来帮助理解这段经文。记住，一段经文只有一个正确的原意，我们的任务是找到它，而不是随意发挥。

第三步是应用，就是问「这段经文对今天的我有什么意义？」具体来说，上帝要我通过这段经文知道什么真理？改变什么态度或想法？采取什么具体的行动？停止什么不好的行为？应用要具体、可操作，不要停留在「我要更爱上帝」这种笼统的层面，而是想清楚这周你可以做什么不同的事。

一些实用的小技巧：每次读经前先祷告，求圣灵打开你的心和眼睛；用笔记本记录你的观察和想法；一次专注读一小段，大概五到十节就够了，不要贪多嚼不烂；同一段经文多读几遍，每次都会有新的发现；找一本好的注释书或者查经材料来帮助你理解难懂的段落；跟别人一起分享讨论，你会受到很大的启发。

记住最重要的一点：圣经是上帝活泼的话语，而圣灵是你最好的老师。方法只是工具，真正让你明白圣经的是圣灵的光照。带着谦卑和渴慕的心来读，上帝一定会向你说话。
content_en:
Reading the Bible isn't like speed-reading a novel from cover to cover. Scripture requires careful, methodical reading. Here's a classic, practical approach called 'Inductive Bible Study' — consisting of three steps: Observation, Interpretation, and Application. Master this method and your Bible reading will no longer feel aimless.

Step one is Observation: carefully read the passage and ask yourself, 'What does this text actually say?' Notice key elements: What are the keywords? Are there repeated words? Are there contrasts or transitions? What characters appear? Where and when does it take place? What's the author's tone? Don't rush to conclusions or jump to application — first gather all clues and information like a detective. Good observation is the foundation of correct understanding.

Step two is Interpretation: ask, 'What did this passage originally mean? What was the author actually trying to communicate?' This step requires considering several important factors: historical background — what was happening at that time; cultural context — how people of that era understood these words; literary context — what the surrounding passages discuss; genre — is it poetry, narrative, epistle, prophecy, or something else? The core principle is 'Scripture interprets Scripture' — using other parts of the Bible to understand a passage. Remember, a passage has only one correct original meaning; our task is to find it, not to improvise.

Step three is Application: ask, 'What does this passage mean for me today?' Specifically: What truth does God want me to know through this passage? What attitude or thinking should I change? What concrete action should I take? What harmful behavior should I stop? Application should be specific and actionable — don't stay at the vague level of 'I should love God more,' but think clearly about what you can do differently this week.

Some practical tips: pray before each reading, asking the Holy Spirit to open your heart and eyes; use a notebook to record observations and thoughts; focus on a small section at a time — about five to ten verses is enough, don't bite off more than you can chew; read the same passage multiple times — you'll discover something new each time; get a good commentary or study guide to help with difficult passages; share and discuss with others — you'll gain tremendous insight.

Remember the most important point: the Bible is God's living Word, and the Holy Spirit is your best teacher. Methods are just tools; what truly helps you understand Scripture is the Spirit's illumination. Come with a humble, hungry heart, and God will surely speak to you.

title_zh: 如何在学校做基督徒
title_en: How to Be a Christian at School
content_zh:
在学校做基督徒，不是要你站在桌子上大喊"我信耶稣！"，而是要活出基督的样式。你的生活就是你最好的见证。

在学业上：
诚实考试，不作弊
按时完成作业，为神的荣耀努力——学习是对上帝创造的探索，无论数学、科学、文学、历史，都能显明上帝的荣耀和智慧
帮助同学学习，分享笔记，用所学的知识帮助别人
尊重老师，即使你不同意他们的观点
追求卓越而不是完美主义——上帝要我们尽力，但好成绩是恩典，坏成绩不是咒诅

在人际关系上：
对每个人都友善，包括被边缘化的同学
不参与恶意八卦和霸凌
在冲突中做和平使者
用行动显示什么叫"爱人如己"

在价值观上：
温和但坚定地表达你的信仰立场
不用"基督教术语"吓跑别人，用正常语言分享
为朋友祷告，但不强迫他们信教
活出喜乐和平安，让人好奇你为什么不一样

在品格塑造上：
在困难学科中学习坚持，在容易学科中学习谦卑
品格的培养比知识的积累更重要
学习技能也是服侍的装备——未来无论做什么工作，都可以荣耀上帝

记住：你可能是某些同学认识的唯一基督徒。他们对基督教的印象很可能来自于你。不用完美，但要真实。当你犯错时，勇敢道歉；当有机会时，自然分享你的信仰。
content_en:
Being a Christian at school doesn't mean standing on desks shouting "I believe in Jesus!" — it means living like Christ. Your life is your best testimony.

In academics:
Be honest in exams, don't cheat
Complete assignments on time, work hard for God's glory — learning explores God's creation; whether math, science, literature, or history, all can reveal God's glory and wisdom
Help classmates study, share notes, use your knowledge to help others
Respect teachers, even when you disagree with their views
Pursue excellence, not perfectionism — God wants our best effort, but good grades are grace, bad grades aren't curses

In relationships:
Be kind to everyone, including marginalized students
Don't participate in malicious gossip or bullying
Be a peacemaker in conflicts
Show what "love your neighbor" looks like in action

In values:
Express your beliefs gently but firmly
Don't use "Christian jargon" that scares people off
Pray for friends, but don't pressure them
Live with joy and peace that makes people curious why you're different

In character building:
Learn perseverance in difficult subjects, humility in easy ones
Character development matters more than knowledge accumulation
Learning skills equips you for service — whatever career you pursue can glorify God

Remember: You might be the only Christian some classmates know. Their impression of Christianity might come from you. You don't have to be perfect, but be authentic. When you mess up, apologize courageously; when opportunities arise, share your faith naturally.

title_zh: 十诫简明版：上帝的智慧指南
title_en: Ten Commandments Simplified: God's Wisdom Guide
content_zh:
十诫不是上帝要控制你、限制你自由的一张清单，而是一份充满爱的智慧指南！就像父母对孩子说「不要碰火炉」不是为了控制孩子，而是为了保护孩子不受伤。上帝比任何人都了解什么会伤害我们、什么会让我们真正幸福，所以祂给了我们这些指引。

十诫分为两组。前四条是关于我们和上帝的关系——如何爱上帝：第一条，除我以外不可有别的神。上帝要在你生命中占据首位，不是分数、不是男女朋友、不是手机游戏，而是上帝。第二条，不可造偶像崇拜。偶像不只是木头石头做的雕像，任何取代上帝在你心中位置的东西都是偶像——金钱、名声、外貌、别人的认可。第三条，不可妄称上帝的名。要认真对待上帝的名字，不随便拿来开玩笑或者发假誓。第四条，守安息日。上帝设计了工作和休息的节奏，定期停下来安静敬拜、恢复精力，这是上帝对我们身心的保护。

后六条是关于我们和他人的关系——如何爱人：第五条，孝敬父母。尊重和感恩养育你的人，即使你不同意他们的每一个决定。第六条，不可杀人。耶稣进一步说明，心中的仇恨也是一种谋杀。第七条，不可奸淫。上帝设计的婚姻关系是神圣的，要保守你的心思意念和身体。第八条，不可偷盗。不只是偷东西，考试作弊、抄袭也算。第九条，不可作假见证。不说谎、不造谣、不搬弄是非。第十条，不可贪心。不羡慕嫉妒别人拥有的东西，学会知足感恩。

这些诫命不是得救的条件——我们靠恩典得救，不靠守律法。没有一个人能完美地遵守所有诫命，这恰恰说明我们需要耶稣的救恩。但十诫显示了上帝设计的美好生活方式。当我们照这样生活，我们更快乐，关系更健康，社会更和谐。十诫像高速公路上的护栏，不是限制你的自由，而是保护你不掉进痛苦的深渊。

耶稣把全部十条诫命总结为两条：尽心尽力爱上帝，爱人如己。一切律法和先知的教导都建立在这两条上面。当你真正学会爱，你就自然会活出十诫的精神。
content_en:
The Ten Commandments aren't a list from God to control you or restrict your freedom — they're a wisdom guide filled with love! Like parents telling a child 'don't touch the stove' — not to control the child but to protect them from getting burned. God understands better than anyone what will harm us and what will make us truly happy, so He gave us these guidelines.

The commandments are divided into two groups. The first four concern our relationship with God — how to love God: First, have no other gods before Me. God should hold first place in your life — not grades, not a boyfriend or girlfriend, not mobile games, but God. Second, don't make idols to worship. Idols aren't just wooden or stone statues; anything that replaces God's position in your heart is an idol — money, fame, appearance, others' approval. Third, don't misuse God's name. Take God's name seriously; don't use it carelessly for jokes or false oaths. Fourth, keep the Sabbath. God designed a rhythm of work and rest; regularly stopping to quietly worship and recharge is God's protection for our body and mind.

The last six concern our relationships with others — how to love people: Fifth, honor your parents. Respect and appreciate those who raised you, even when you disagree with every decision they make. Sixth, don't murder. Jesus further explained that hatred in your heart is also a form of murder. Seventh, don't commit adultery. God's design for marriage is sacred; guard your thoughts and body. Eighth, don't steal — and this includes not just physical theft but exam cheating and plagiarism too. Ninth, don't bear false witness. Don't lie, don't spread rumors, don't gossip. Tenth, don't covet. Don't envy what others have; learn contentment and gratitude.

These commandments aren't conditions for salvation — we're saved by grace, not by keeping the law. No one can perfectly keep all the commandments, which precisely demonstrates our need for Jesus' salvation. But the commandments reveal God's design for a flourishing life. When we live this way, we're happier, relationships are healthier, and society is more harmonious. The commandments are like highway guardrails — not restricting your freedom but protecting you from falling into painful ditches.

Jesus summarized all ten commandments into two: love God with all your heart and strength, and love others as yourself. All the law and prophets' teaching rests on these two. When you truly learn to love, you'll naturally live out the spirit of the Ten Commandments.

十诫如何保护我们，而不是限制我们？How do the commandments protect rather than restrict us?
你觉得哪一条诫命最容易被误解？Which commandment do you think is most misunderstood?

title_zh: 恩典vs行为：我们如何被接纳？
title_en: Grace vs. Works: How Are We Accepted?
content_zh:
这是基督教跟世界上几乎所有其他宗教和道德体系最核心的区别：我们不是因为自己「够好」而被上帝接纳，而是完完全全因为上帝白白赐给我们的恩典！

很多宗教和哲学的核心思想是「做好事积功德，最终得到奖赏」。做够了好事就上天堂，做了坏事就受惩罚——听起来很公平对吧？但基督教说的完全不同。圣经告诉我们「世人都犯了罪，亏缺了神的荣耀」（罗马书三章二十三节）。上帝的标准不是「还不错」，而是「完美」。就像一场考试要一百分才算及格，你考了九十八分，别人觉得很了不起，但九十八分还是不及格。我们最好的行为在上帝完美的标准面前仍然不够，因为罪已经污染了我们做一切事情的动机。

但好消息来了！耶稣替我们考了满分。祂活出了完美的生命，没有犯过一个罪，然后在十字架上代替我们接受了不及格的惩罚。当我们相信耶稣的时候，上帝就把耶稣完美的成绩单放在我们名下。这就是恩典——不是我们配得的，不是我们赚来的，而是上帝白白送给我们的礼物。「你们得救是本乎恩，也因着信。这并不是出于自己，乃是神所赐的；也不是出于行为，免得有人自夸」（以弗所书二章八至九节）。

那有人可能会问：既然靠恩典得救，为什么还要做好事呢？这个问题非常好！答案是：我们做好事不是为了得救，而是因为已经得救了。就像收到朋友送的珍贵礼物后你会写感谢信——不是为了赚取那份礼物，而是因为你已经收到了，心里充满感恩。一个真正经历了上帝恩典的人，自然会想要活出感恩的生命，自然会想要爱上帝、爱别人。好行为是救恩的果子，不是救恩的根基。

这个真理给我们带来两个巨大的礼物。第一是安全感。你不需要每天担心自己「做得够不够好」才能被上帝爱。上帝对你的爱不取决于你的表现，而取决于基督已经做成的工作。即使你今天失败了，上帝的爱依然不变。第二是动力。当你知道自己已经被完全接纳，你不是出于恐惧去做好事，而是出于爱和感恩。这种动力比恐惧强大太多了，也持久太多了。恩典不会让人放纵，恩典让人感恩，感恩的心是世上最强大的改变力量。
content_en:
This is the most fundamental distinction between Christianity and virtually every other religion and moral system in the world: we're not accepted by God because we're 'good enough' — it's entirely and completely because of God's freely given grace!

The core idea of many religions and philosophies is 'do good deeds, accumulate merit, eventually earn rewards.' Do enough good and you go to heaven; do bad and face punishment — sounds fair, right? But Christianity says something entirely different. The Bible tells us, 'All have sinned and fall short of the glory of God' (Romans 3:23). God's standard isn't 'pretty good' — it's 'perfect.' Like an exam where you need one hundred percent to pass: you score ninety-eight, and everyone thinks that's impressive, but ninety-eight still fails. Our best actions before God's perfect standard still aren't enough, because sin has contaminated the motivation behind everything we do.

But here's the good news! Jesus scored perfect for us. He lived a flawless life without committing a single sin, then on the cross took the punishment of our failing grade in our place. When we believe in Jesus, God places Jesus' perfect report card under our name. This is grace — not what we deserve, not what we earned, but a gift God freely gives. 'For it is by grace you have been saved, through faith — and this is not from yourselves, it is the gift of God — not by works, so that no one can boast' (Ephesians 2:8-9).

Someone might ask: if we're saved by grace, why do good deeds at all? Great question! The answer: we do good not to earn salvation but because we're already saved. Like writing a thank-you note after receiving a precious gift from a friend — not to earn the gift but because you've already received it and your heart overflows with gratitude. Someone who's truly experienced God's grace naturally wants to live a grateful life, naturally wants to love God and love others. Good works are the fruit of salvation, not its foundation.

This truth brings us two enormous gifts. First, security. You don't need to worry daily whether you're 'good enough' to be loved by God. God's love for you doesn't depend on your performance but on the work Christ already completed. Even if you fail today, God's love remains unchanged. Second, motivation. When you know you're already fully accepted, you don't do good out of fear but out of love and gratitude. This motivation is far more powerful and lasting than fear. Grace doesn't lead to indulgence — grace produces gratitude, and a grateful heart is the most powerful force for change in the world.
