title_zh: 创世记导读：一切的开始
title_en: Genesis Guide: Where It All Begins
content_zh:
创世记是圣经的第一卷书，希伯来文名字的意思是「起初」，讲述了宇宙、人类和救赎计划的开始。这卷书由摩西所写，大约涵盖了从创造到约瑟去世超过两千年的历史，是整本圣经的根基。

前十一章是「史前史」：上帝用话语创造天地万物，按着自己的形象造人，赋予人管理全地的使命。但亚当夏娃在伊甸园犯罪堕落，罪从此进入世界，带来死亡和咒诅。该隐杀弟弟亚伯，罪恶不断蔓延。上帝用洪水审判世界，但因恩典保全了挪亚一家。巴别塔事件显示人类联合起来也不过是自高自大、抵挡上帝。这些故事回答了人生最根本的问题：我从哪里来？为什么世界有苦难？人的尊严从何而来？

从第十二章开始进入「列祖史」：上帝呼召亚伯拉罕离开本地本族父家，应许他的后裔要成为大国，万国要因他得福。这个应许贯穿整本圣经，最终在耶稣基督身上完全实现。以撒是应许之子，雅各虽然诡诈却蒙上帝拣选改名为以色列，约瑟被哥哥们卖到埃及却成为拯救全家的人。约瑟的名言「从前你们的意思是要害我，但上帝的意思原是好的」完美总结了创世记的主题。

关键主题包括：上帝的主权创造与护理、人按上帝形象被造的尊严、罪的严重后果与蔓延、恩典之约的应许、上帝信实地成就祂的计划。值得背诵的经文包括创世记一章一节「起初上帝创造天地」和十五章六节「亚伯兰信耶和华，耶和华就以此为他的义」。

这卷书与福音的关联极其紧密。创世记三章十五节被称为「第一个福音」：女人的后裔要伤蛇的头，这是圣经第一次预言救主耶稣。亚伯拉罕献以撒预表上帝献出独生子。约瑟被弃绝却成为拯救者，正如基督被钉十字架却成就救恩。

对你来说，创世记告诉我们：你不是偶然存在的，你是上帝精心创造的；这个世界虽然破碎，但上帝有一个伟大的拯救计划，而这个计划的中心就是耶稣基督。无论你经历什么困难，上帝都能化咒诅为祝福。
content_en:
Genesis is the Bible's first book — its Hebrew name means 'In the Beginning' — telling the story of the universe, humanity, and God's rescue plan. Written by Moses, it covers over two thousand years of history from creation to Joseph's death, serving as the foundation for the entire Bible.

The first eleven chapters are 'primeval history': God creates everything by His word, makes humans in His own image, and gives them the mission to steward the earth. But Adam and Eve sin in the Garden of Eden, and sin enters the world bringing death and curse. Cain murders his brother Abel, and evil keeps spreading. God judges the world through the flood but graciously preserves Noah's family. The Tower of Babel shows that even united humanity only manages arrogance and rebellion against God. These stories answer life's most fundamental questions: Where do I come from? Why is there suffering? Where does human dignity originate?

From chapter twelve begins the 'patriarchal history': God calls Abraham to leave his homeland, promising that his descendants will become a great nation and all peoples will be blessed through him. This promise runs through the entire Bible and finds its ultimate fulfillment in Jesus Christ. Isaac is the child of promise; Jacob, though deceitful, is chosen by God and renamed Israel; Joseph is sold into Egypt by his brothers yet becomes their family's savior. Joseph's famous words — 'You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good' — perfectly summarize Genesis's theme.

Key themes include: God's sovereign creation and providence, human dignity as image-bearers, the serious consequences and spread of sin, the promise of a covenant of grace, and God's faithfulness in accomplishing His plan. Memorable verses include Genesis 1:1 ('In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth') and 15:6 ('Abram believed the LORD, and he credited it to him as righteousness').

This book connects to the Gospel profoundly. Genesis 3:15 is called the 'first Gospel': the woman's offspring will crush the serpent's head — Scripture's first prophecy of Jesus the Savior. Abraham offering Isaac foreshadows God offering His only Son. Joseph, rejected yet becoming savior, mirrors Christ crucified yet accomplishing salvation.

For you personally, Genesis declares: you're not here by accident — you're God's intentional creation. Though this world is broken, God has a grand rescue plan centered on Jesus Christ. Whatever difficulties you face, God can turn curses into blessings.

title_zh: 出埃及记导读：救赎的故事
content_zh:
出埃及记是一个关于救赎的史诗故事，也是整本圣经中最重要的救恩叙事之一。这卷书由摩西所写，记录了以色列人从埃及为奴到成为上帝子民的过程，时间大约在公元前一千五百年。

故事的背景是以色列人在埃及做了四百年奴隶，受尽苦待和压迫。但上帝听见了他们的哀声，记念与亚伯拉罕所立的约。祂兴起摩西，一个在皇宫长大却逃亡旷野四十年的人，差遣他回去面对法老，宣告「容我的百姓去」。十灾显示上帝胜过法老和埃及一切假神，每一灾都直接挑战埃及人崇拜的偶像。最后一灾——击杀长子——最为震撼，逾越节羔羊的血涂在门框上使以色列人得以存活，这正是基督为我们牺牲的预表。

红海分开是上帝大能拯救的高潮：以色列人走干地过海，追兵却被淹没。摩西和百姓唱歌赞美：「耶和华是我的力量，我的诗歌，也成了我的拯救。」在西奈山，上帝颁布律法，包括十诫，建立与以色列的约，宣告「你们要归我作祭司的国度，为圣洁的国民」。金牛犊事件暴露人心的悖逆——刚刚经历神迹就转去拜偶像——但上帝仍然怜悯赦免。会幕的建造说明上帝想要住在祂百姓中间，祂的荣耀充满会幕。

关键主题包括：上帝信守祂的约、救赎是上帝主动的恩典、律法显明上帝的圣洁标准、敬拜的核心是上帝的同在。值得记住的经文包括三章十四节上帝的名「我是自有永有的」和十九章五至六节「你们要归我作祭司的国度」。

这整个故事完美预表新约的救赎：我们都是罪的奴隶，上帝通过耶稣——真正的逾越节羔羊——拯救我们，用祂的血与我们立新约，赐下圣灵住在我们里面，带领我们走向天上的应许之地。出埃及不只是历史事件，更是每个基督徒的属灵经历：从黑暗进入光明，从奴役得到自由，从没有盼望到成为上帝的儿女。
content_en:
Exodus is an epic story of redemption and one of the most important salvation narratives in the entire Bible. Written by Moses, it records Israel's journey from slavery in Egypt to becoming God's people, around 1500 BC.

The backdrop: the Israelites had been slaves in Egypt for four hundred years, enduring harsh oppression. But God heard their cries and remembered His covenant with Abraham. He raised up Moses — a man raised in the palace who fled to the wilderness for forty years — and sent him back to confront Pharaoh with the declaration: 'Let my people go.' The ten plagues demonstrated God's victory over Pharaoh and every false god of Egypt, each plague directly challenging an Egyptian idol. The final plague — the death of the firstborn — was most devastating; the Passover lamb's blood on the doorframe spared the Israelites, a perfect foreshadowing of Christ's sacrifice for us.

The parting of the Red Sea is the climax of God's mighty deliverance: Israel walked on dry ground while the pursuing army was swallowed up. Moses and the people sang in praise: 'The LORD is my strength and my song; he has become my salvation.' At Mount Sinai, God gave the Law including the Ten Commandments, establishing His covenant with Israel and declaring: 'You will be for me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation.' The golden calf incident exposed the human heart's rebellion — worshiping idols right after witnessing miracles — yet God still showed mercy and forgiveness. The tabernacle's construction showed that God desired to dwell among His people, His glory filling the tabernacle.

Key themes include: God's covenant faithfulness, redemption as God's initiative of grace, the Law revealing God's holy standard, and worship centered on God's presence. Memorable verses include 3:14 where God reveals His name ('I AM WHO I AM') and 19:5-6 ('You will be my kingdom of priests').

This entire story perfectly foreshadows New Testament redemption: we are all slaves to sin, God rescues us through Jesus — the true Passover Lamb — establishes a new covenant with His blood, gives us the Holy Spirit to dwell within us, and leads us toward the heavenly Promised Land. Exodus isn't just history — it's every Christian's spiritual experience: from darkness into light, from slavery to freedom, from hopelessness to becoming God's children.

title_zh: 诗篇导读：心灵的歌声
title_en: Psalms Guide: Songs of the Soul
content_zh:
诗篇是圣经中的歌本和祷告册，共一百五十篇，是以色列人在敬拜中使用了数百年的诗歌集。作者包括大卫（写了约七十三篇）、亚萨、可拉后裔、所罗门、摩西等。诗篇不是按时间顺序排列的，而是分成五卷，每卷以颂赞结束，呼应摩西五经的结构。

诗篇表达了人类各种真实的情感：喜乐、感恩、恐惧、愤怒、困惑、哀伤、盼望。这些不是「属灵正确」的表面文字，而是诗人在真实处境中发出的原始呼声。你会看到大卫在被扫罗追杀时恳求上帝拯救，在犯罪后痛悔认罪，在得胜时欢呼赞美。诗人会对敌人愤怒，对上帝的沉默困惑，在绝望中哭泣，也在黑夜过后歌唱。

诗篇的种类丰富多样：赞美诗歌颂上帝的伟大（如诗篇一百零四篇），哀歌在痛苦中向上帝呼求（如诗篇二十二篇），感恩诗记念上帝的帮助（如诗篇三十篇），智慧诗教导敬虔生活（如诗篇一篇），弥赛亚诗篇预言基督（如诗篇二十二篇和一百一十篇）。

关键信息是：你可以把任何情感带到上帝面前！祂不怕你的愤怒、疑惑或眼泪。诗篇教我们如何诚实地祷告，如何在困难中仍然信靠上帝，如何从自己的感受转向上帝的信实。值得背诵的经文太多了，比如诗篇二十三篇「耶和华是我的牧者」，诗篇四十六篇一节「上帝是我们的避难所」，诗篇一百一十九篇一百零五节「你的话是我脚前的灯」。

诗篇与福音的关联深刻：耶稣在十字架上引用诗篇二十二篇「我的上帝，我的上帝，为什么离弃我」，诗篇十六篇预言基督的复活，诗篇一百一十篇宣告基督是永远的祭司。耶稣自己说诗篇中有关于祂的预言。

对你来说，诗篇是最好的祷告学校。无论你今天是开心还是难过，是充满信心还是满腹疑惑，打开诗篇，找到与你心情共鸣的那一篇，然后学习诗人如何把一切带到上帝面前。
content_en:
Psalms is the Bible's songbook and prayer book — 150 poems that Israel used in worship for centuries. Authors include David (about 73 psalms), Asaph, the sons of Korah, Solomon, Moses, and others. They're not arranged chronologically but divided into five books, each ending with praise, mirroring the five books of Moses.

Psalms express every genuine human emotion: joy, gratitude, fear, anger, confusion, grief, hope. These aren't spiritually polished surface words but raw cries from real situations. You'll see David begging God for rescue while hunted by Saul, weeping in repentance after sin, shouting praise after victory. Psalmists rage at enemies, wrestle with God's silence, weep in despair, and sing after the darkness passes.

The variety is rich: praise psalms celebrating God's greatness (like Psalm 104), laments crying out in pain (like Psalm 22), thanksgiving psalms remembering God's help (like Psalm 30), wisdom psalms teaching godly living (like Psalm 1), and messianic psalms prophesying Christ (like Psalms 22 and 110).

The key message: you can bring any emotion before God! He's not afraid of your anger, doubt, or tears. Psalms teach us to pray honestly, to trust God amid difficulty, and to turn from our feelings toward God's faithfulness. There are so many verses worth memorizing: Psalm 23 ('The LORD is my shepherd'), Psalm 46:1 ('God is our refuge'), Psalm 119:105 ('Your word is a lamp for my feet').

Psalms connect deeply to the Gospel: Jesus quoted Psalm 22 on the cross — 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?' Psalm 16 prophesies Christ's resurrection. Psalm 110 declares Christ as eternal priest. Jesus Himself said the Psalms contain prophecies about Him.

For you, Psalms is the best school of prayer. Whether you're happy or sad today, full of faith or full of doubt, open the Psalms, find one that resonates with your heart, and learn how the psalmist brought everything before God.

title_zh: 箴言导读：生活的智慧
content_zh:
箴言是实用的生活手册，充满了智慧的短句和原则。主要作者是所罗门，圣经记载他是历史上最有智慧的王，因为他年轻时向上帝求智慧而不是财富。这卷书收集了来自不同时期的智慧话语，大约在公元前十世纪成书。

首先要明白箴言的文体特点：这是智慧文学，不是应许书。不是说「如果你这样做，上帝保证会这样回报你」，而是一般性原则——通常情况下什么是明智的选择。比如「教养孩童使他走当行的道」是智慧原则，不是铁律。理解这一点很重要，否则当现实与箴言不符时会对上帝失望。

箴言的核心主题是「敬畏耶和华是知识的开端」。真正的智慧不是聪明才智或学历高，而是认识上帝、按祂的心意生活。前九章用拟人手法描写智慧女士和愚昧妇人的对比，呼召年轻人选择智慧的道路。十章到三十一章是具体的智慧格言，涵盖生活的各个领域：金钱管理（要慷慨不要贪婪）、朋友关系（要选择益友远离损友）、工作伦理（勤劳蒙福懒惰受苦）、言语的力量（舌头能造就也能毁灭）、性纯洁（远离淫乱保守自己）、酒精（不要被酒控制）、骄傲与谦卑（骄傲在败坏以先）。

箴言特别警告几种人：愚昧人拒绝智慧、自以为是，懒惰人总有借口不肯做事，骄傲人不肯受教，好争吵的人给自己和别人带来麻烦。它赞扬勤劳、谦卑、诚实、慷慨、节制的品格。三十一章的才德妇人是敬虔女性的典范。

箴言与福音的关联在于：真正的智慧就是基督自己。保罗说基督是「上帝的智慧」。离开基督，人的智慧不过是愚拙。敬畏上帝是一切智慧的根基，而敬畏上帝首先就是信靠福音。

对青少年来说，箴言特别宝贵，因为你们正在做很多影响一生的重要决定：交什么朋友、怎么用时间、如何面对诱惑。建议每天读一章（三十一章正好对应一个月），让这些智慧慢慢塑造你的品格和判断力。
content_en:
Proverbs is a practical life manual packed with wise sayings and principles. The main author is Solomon, whom the Bible records as history's wisest king because he asked God for wisdom rather than wealth in his youth. This book collects wisdom sayings from various periods, compiled around the tenth century BC.

First, understand Proverbs' literary nature: it's wisdom literature, not a promise book. It doesn't say 'if you do this, God guarantees that result,' but offers general principles — what's usually the wise choice. For example, 'Train up a child in the way he should go' is a wisdom principle, not an iron law. Understanding this matters, otherwise you'll be disappointed with God when reality doesn't match a proverb.

The core theme is 'The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge.' True wisdom isn't about intelligence or degrees but knowing God and living according to His will. Chapters 1-9 personify Lady Wisdom and Lady Folly in contrast, calling young people to choose wisdom's path. Chapters 10-31 contain specific wisdom sayings covering every area of life: money management (be generous, not greedy), friendships (choose good friends, avoid bad ones), work ethic (diligence brings blessing, laziness brings suffering), the power of words (the tongue can build up or destroy), sexual purity (flee immorality, guard yourself), alcohol (don't be controlled by wine), pride versus humility (pride goes before destruction).

Proverbs especially warns about certain types: fools who reject wisdom and are self-righteous, the lazy who always have excuses, the proud who refuse correction, the quarrelsome who bring trouble to themselves and others. It commends diligence, humility, honesty, generosity, and self-control. The virtuous woman of chapter 31 exemplifies godly womanhood.

Proverbs connects to the Gospel because true wisdom is Christ Himself. Paul says Christ is 'the wisdom of God.' Apart from Christ, human wisdom is foolishness. Fearing God is the foundation of all wisdom, and fearing God begins with trusting the Gospel.

For teenagers, Proverbs is especially valuable because you're making many life-shaping decisions right now: what friends to keep, how to spend your time, how to face temptation. Try reading one chapter per day (31 chapters perfectly fit one month), letting this wisdom gradually shape your character and judgment.
discussion_questions: 箴言中哪句话最挑战你？Which verse in Proverbs challenges you most?
青少年最需要箴言中的哪种智慧？What wisdom from Proverbs do teenagers need most?
你如何区分'一般原则'和'绝对承诺'？How do you distinguish between 'general principles' and 'absolute promises'?

title_zh: 马太福音导读：王的福音
title_en: Matthew Guide: The Gospel of the King
content_zh:
马太福音是新约的第一卷书，由税吏出身的使徒马太所写，主要写给犹太读者，要证明耶稣就是旧约预言的弥赛亚君王。这卷书大约写于公元六十年代，是四福音书中最有系统地记录耶稣教导的一卷。

从耶稣的家谱开始，马太刻意追溯到亚伯拉罕和大卫，显示耶稣是亚伯拉罕的后裔、大卫的子孙，是上帝应许的那一位。博士从东方来朝拜婴孩耶稣，显示祂不只是以色列的王，更是万国的王。希律王的屠杀和逃往埃及呼应了以色列的历史，耶稣是真正的以色列。

马太特别强调耶稣的教导，记录了五段重要讲论。登山宝训（第五到七章）是天国伦理的总纲：八福描绘天国子民的品格，主祷文教导如何祷告，金律「你们愿意人怎样待你们，你们也要怎样待人」总结律法精神。第十三章的天国比喻（撒种、稗子、芥菜种、面酵等）解释上帝国度的奥秘和运作方式。第二十三章严厉批评宗教领袖的假冒伪善。第二十四到二十五章预言末世和基督再来。

耶稣行了许多神迹：医治病人、赶出污鬼、平静风浪、喂饱五千人，证明祂有上帝的权柄。但犹太宗教领袖拒绝接受祂，认为祂亵渎上帝。最终，这位真正的王被钉在十字架上，头上挂着「犹太人的王」的牌子。但第三天祂从死里复活，证明祂真是上帝的儿子、弥赛亚、永远的君王。

大使命（二十八章十八到二十节）结束全书：「天上地下所有的权柄都赐给我了。所以你们要去，使万民作我的门徒。」这不是建议，而是王的命令。马太想告诉每个读者：耶稣不只是一个好老师或道德榜样，祂是至高的王，配得我们完全的顺服和敬拜。

对你来说，马太福音挑战你思考：耶稣到底是谁？如果祂真是王，那你的生活应该有什么改变？跟随祂不是周末的爱好，而是全生命的委身。
content_en:
Matthew's Gospel is the New Testament's first book, written by the apostle Matthew — a former tax collector — primarily for Jewish readers, proving Jesus is the Messiah King prophesied in the Old Testament. Written around the AD 60s, it's the most systematic record of Jesus' teaching among the four Gospels.

Starting with Jesus' genealogy, Matthew deliberately traces back to Abraham and David, showing Jesus as Abraham's descendant and David's son — the promised One. Wise men from the East worship the infant Jesus, revealing He's not just Israel's King but King of all nations. Herod's massacre and the flight to Egypt echo Israel's history; Jesus is the true Israel.

Matthew especially emphasizes Jesus' teaching, recording five major discourses. The Sermon on the Mount (chapters 5-7) is the charter of Kingdom ethics: the Beatitudes portray Kingdom citizens' character, the Lord's Prayer teaches how to pray, and the Golden Rule — 'Do to others what you would have them do to you' — summarizes the Law's spirit. Chapter 13's Kingdom parables (sower, weeds, mustard seed, yeast) explain God's Kingdom mysteries and workings. Chapter 23 sharply rebukes religious leaders' hypocrisy. Chapters 24-25 prophesy the end times and Christ's return.

Jesus performed many miracles: healing the sick, casting out demons, calming storms, feeding five thousand — proving His divine authority. But Jewish religious leaders rejected Him, accusing Him of blasphemy. Ultimately, this true King was crucified with the sign 'King of the Jews' above His head. But on the third day He rose from the dead, proving He truly is God's Son, the Messiah, the eternal King.

The Great Commission (28:18-20) concludes the book: 'All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me. Therefore go and make disciples of all nations.' This isn't a suggestion — it's a King's command. Matthew wants every reader to know: Jesus isn't merely a good teacher or moral example — He's the supreme King who deserves our complete obedience and worship.

For you, Matthew's Gospel challenges you to consider: Who is Jesus really? If He truly is King, how should your life change? Following Him isn't a weekend hobby but a whole-life commitment.
discussion_questions: 耶稣作为王对你的日常生活意味着什么？What does Jesus as King mean for your daily life?
登山宝训中哪个教导最挑战你？Which teaching in the Sermon on the Mount challenges you most?
你如何向朋友解释耶稣是王？How would you explain to friends that Jesus is King?

title_zh: 罗马书导读：救恩的逻辑
title_en: Romans Guide: The Logic of Salvation
content_zh:
罗马书是使徒保罗写给罗马教会的书信，被称为基督教信仰的「系统神学手册」，大约写于公元五十七年。保罗当时还没去过罗马，但计划前往，所以提前系统地阐述福音核心真理。

前三章描述人类的困境：所有人都犯了罪，亏缺了上帝的荣耀。外邦人有自然启示却不认识上帝，犹太人有律法却守不住。没有义人，连一个也没有。这个诊断很残酷但真实——不先认识病情就不会珍惜药方。

第三章末到第四章是福音核心：因信称义。上帝的义因信耶稣基督加给一切相信的人。亚伯拉罕因信称义说明这原则从旧约就有了。第五章对比亚当和基督：亚当带来定罪和死亡，基督带来称义和生命。

第六到八章解释称义后的生活。我们向罪死了，靠圣灵活着。第七章诚实描写信徒内心挣扎。第八章是圣经最荣耀的章节之一：在基督耶稣里不再被定罪！圣灵住在我们里面，万事互相效力叫爱上帝的人得益处。谁能使我们与基督的爱隔绝？什么都不能！

第九到十一章讨论以色列在上帝计划中的位置。第十二到十六章是实际生活指南：将身体献上当作活祭，不要效法世界，要心意更新变化。值得背诵的经文包括三章二十三节、六章二十三节、八章二十八节和八章三十八到三十九节。

对你来说，罗马书回答最根本的问题：有罪的人如何与圣洁的上帝和好？答案不是努力做好人，而是信靠耶稣基督。
content_en:
Romans is Paul's letter to the Roman church, often called Christianity's 'systematic theology handbook,' written around AD 57. Paul hadn't yet visited Rome but planned to, so he systematically presented the Gospel's core truths in advance.

The first three chapters diagnose humanity's condition: all have sinned and fall short of God's glory. Gentiles had natural revelation but didn't acknowledge God; Jews had the Law but couldn't keep it. There is no righteous person — not even one. This diagnosis is brutal but honest — without recognizing the disease, we won't treasure the cure.

Late chapter 3 through chapter 4 presents the Gospel's core: justification by faith. God's righteousness comes through faith in Jesus Christ to all who believe. Abraham was justified by faith, proving this principle existed from the Old Testament. Chapter 5 contrasts Adam and Christ: Adam brought condemnation and death; Christ brought justification and life.

Chapters 6-8 explain life after justification. We died to sin and live by the Spirit. Chapter 7 honestly describes believers' inner struggle. Chapter 8 is one of Scripture's most glorious chapters: no condemnation for those in Christ Jesus! The Spirit dwells in us; all things work together for the good of those who love God. Who can separate us from Christ's love? Nothing can!

Chapters 9-11 discuss Israel's place in God's plan. Chapters 12-16 offer practical living guidance: offer your bodies as living sacrifices; don't conform to this world but be transformed by renewing your mind. Verses worth memorizing include 3:23, 6:23, 8:28, and 8:38-39.

For you, Romans answers the most fundamental question: How can sinful people be reconciled to a holy God? The answer isn't trying harder — it's trusting Jesus Christ.
discussion_questions: 因信称义如何改变你看自己的方式？How does justification by faith change how you see yourself?
为什么保罗花这么多时间论证人人都有罪？Why does Paul spend so much time proving everyone has sinned?
第8章'不被定罪'对你意味着什么？What does 'no condemnation' in chapter 8 mean to you?

title_zh: 约翰福音导读：相信耶稣
content_zh:
约翰福音是四福音书中最独特的一卷，由使徒约翰在晚年（约公元九十年代）所写。与其他三卷不同，约翰福音更像法庭辩论，用精选证据证明耶稣是上帝的儿子，信祂就可以得生命。

约翰从永恒的视角开篇：「太初有道，道与上帝同在，道就是上帝。」这个「道」就是耶稣基督——祂不是被造的，祂就是创造者，从永恒就与父同在。道成了肉身，住在我们中间，充充满满地有恩典有真理。

约翰精选七个神迹（称为「记号」），每个都有特殊含义：水变酒显示耶稣带来新喜乐，医治瘫子和盲人显示祂赐生命和光，喂饱五千人引出「我是生命的粮」，使拉撒路复活证明祂掌管生死。七个「我是」宣告揭示耶稣的神性：生命的粮、世界的光、羊的门、好牧人、复活和生命、道路真理生命、真葡萄树。每一个都宣告：祂不只是指路的人，祂就是那条路。

约翰福音记录精彩的个人对话：尼哥底母需要重生，撒玛利亚妇人得到活水，生来瞎眼的人看见真光。无论你背景如何，都需要耶稣，也都可以来到祂面前。

「相信」在约翰福音出现九十八次。写作目的在二十章三十一节：「记这些事要叫你们信耶稣是基督，是上帝的儿子，并且叫你们信了祂，就可以因祂的名得生命。」最值得背的是三章十六节：「上帝爱世人，甚至将祂的独生子赐给他们，叫一切信祂的不致灭亡，反得永生。」

对你来说，约翰福音发出直接邀请：你相信耶稣是谁吗？如果你还在寻找，这卷书就是为你写的。
content_en:
John's Gospel is the most distinctive of the four Gospels, written by the apostle John in his later years (around the AD 90s). Unlike the other three, John reads more like a courtroom argument, presenting carefully selected evidence to prove Jesus is God's Son and believing in Him gives life.

John opens from an eternal perspective: 'In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.' This 'Word' is Jesus Christ — not created but the Creator Himself, with the Father from eternity. The Word became flesh and dwelt among us, full of grace and truth.

John selected seven miracles (called 'signs'), each with special significance: water to wine shows Jesus brings new joy; healing the paralytic and blind shows He gives life and light; feeding five thousand introduces 'I am the bread of life'; raising Lazarus proves He commands life and death. Seven 'I am' statements reveal Jesus' divine identity: bread of life, light of the world, gate for the sheep, good shepherd, resurrection and the life, the way the truth and the life, true vine. Each declares: He doesn't just point the way — He IS the way.

John records brilliant personal conversations: Nicodemus needs rebirth, the Samaritan woman receives living water, the man born blind sees the true light. Whatever your background, you need Jesus and can come to Him.

'Believe' appears 98 times in John. The purpose is stated in 20:31: 'These are written that you may believe that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of God, and that by believing you may have life in his name.' The most memorizable verse is 3:16: 'For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.'

For you, John's Gospel extends a direct invitation: Do you believe who Jesus is? If you're still searching, this book was written for you.
discussion_questions: 七个'我是'宣告中哪个最触动你？Which of the seven 'I am' statements touches you most?
约翰为什么这么强调'相信'？Why does John emphasize 'believe' so much?
如何向朋友解释耶稣的神性？How would you explain Jesus' deity to friends?

title_zh: 使徒行传导读：教会的诞生
title_en: Acts Guide: The Church Is Born
content_zh:
使徒行传是教会历史的开篇，由路加所写，是路加福音的续集。这卷书记录了从耶稣升天到保罗在罗马传道约三十年的历史（大约公元三十年到六十年），展示福音如何从耶路撒冷的一小群门徒传遍了整个罗马帝国。

全书的大纲在第一章八节：「圣灵降临在你们身上，你们就必得着能力，并要在耶路撒冷、犹太全地和撒玛利亚，直到地极，作我的见证。」这是一个地理性的扩展：福音从耶路撒冷出发，一圈一圈向外扩展。前半部分以彼得为主角，后半部分以保罗为主角。

五旬节是教会诞生的日子：圣灵如火焰降临在门徒身上，他们开始说方言宣讲上帝的大作为。彼得讲道，三千人悔改信主受洗。初期教会的生活令人向往：恒心遵守使徒的教训，彼此交接，擘饼，祈祷，凡物公用，没有一个人说自己的东西是自己的。

但教会也面临逼迫。司提反成为第一个殉道者，被石头打死时说「主啊，不要将这罪归于他们」。扫罗（后来的保罗）曾积极迫害教会，却在大马士革的路上遇见复活的基督，生命完全翻转。腓利向埃提阿伯太监传福音，彼得在异象中被上帝纠正偏见去向外邦人哥尼流传福音。福音开始突破犹太人的界限。

保罗三次宣教旅程是使徒行传后半部分的主线。他和巴拿巴、西拉、提摩太等同工建立了许多教会，从安提阿到小亚细亚到欧洲。每到一处先去犹太会堂，被拒绝后转向外邦人。保罗被打、被关、被石头砸，但从不放弃传福音。最后被押送到罗马受审，却在那里继续放胆传道。

关键主题包括：圣灵的能力（不是人的能力推动福音）、勇敢的见证（面对逼迫不退缩）、教会的增长（上帝将得救的人数天天加给教会）、福音的普世性（不分犹太人外邦人）。

对你来说，使徒行传挑战你：你愿意像初期教会那样热心传福音吗？同样的圣灵今天也住在每个信徒里面。传福音不需要你完美，只需要你勇敢，靠着圣灵的能力为耶稣作见证。
content_en:
Acts is the opening chapter of church history, written by Luke as a sequel to his Gospel. It records about thirty years from Jesus' ascension to Paul's ministry in Rome (roughly AD 30-60), showing how the Gospel spread from a small group of disciples in Jerusalem throughout the Roman Empire.

The book's outline appears in 1:8: 'You will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes on you; and you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth.' This is a geographic expansion: the Gospel radiates outward from Jerusalem in ever-widening circles. The first half features Peter; the second half features Paul.

Pentecost marks the church's birthday: the Holy Spirit descended like fire on the disciples, and they began speaking in tongues declaring God's mighty works. Peter preached, and three thousand repented, believed, and were baptized. The early church's life was compelling: they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching, fellowship, breaking of bread, and prayer; they shared everything; no one claimed possessions as their own.

But the church also faced persecution. Stephen became the first martyr, saying as he was stoned: 'Lord, do not hold this sin against them.' Saul (later Paul) actively persecuted the church but met the risen Christ on the Damascus road and was completely transformed. Philip shared the Gospel with the Ethiopian eunuch; Peter was corrected by God through a vision to preach to the Gentile Cornelius. The Gospel began breaking through Jewish boundaries.

Paul's three missionary journeys form the second half's main thread. With coworkers like Barnabas, Silas, and Timothy, he planted many churches from Antioch to Asia Minor to Europe. At each stop he went first to the synagogue; when rejected, he turned to Gentiles. Paul was beaten, imprisoned, and stoned, but never stopped preaching. Finally sent to Rome for trial, he continued boldly proclaiming the Gospel there.

Key themes include: the Holy Spirit's power (human effort doesn't drive the Gospel), bold witness (not shrinking from persecution), church growth (the Lord added to their number daily), and the Gospel's universality (no distinction between Jew and Gentile).

For you, Acts poses a challenge: Are you willing to share the Gospel as passionately as the early church? The same Holy Spirit lives in every believer today. Evangelism doesn't require perfection — just courage, empowered by the Spirit, to witness for Jesus.
discussion_questions: 初期教会的哪个特点最吸引你？What early church characteristic attracts you most?
为什么逼迫反而帮助福音传播？Why did persecution actually help Gospel spread?
今天我们如何像使徒那样勇敢见证？How can we witness boldly like the apostles today?

title_zh: 哥林多前书导读：教会问题解答
content_zh:
哥林多前书是保罗写给哥林多教会的书信，大约写于公元五十五年。哥林多是繁华的港口城市，以道德败坏著称，教会深受世俗文化影响，问题丛生。

首先是分党结派（第一到四章）：有人说属保罗，有人说属亚波罗。保罗严厉责备，教会根基是基督不是任何传道人。上帝的智慧是十字架的道理，在世人看为愚拙却是上帝拯救的大能。

然后是道德问题（第五到六章）：教会中有人行淫乱却不处理。保罗说身体是圣灵的殿，要荣耀上帝。第八到十章论吃祭偶像之物——虽有自由但不要绊倒软弱的弟兄，爱比自由更重要。

第十二到十四章论属灵恩赐：教会是基督的身体，每个肢体都重要，恩赐不同但同等宝贵。夹在中间的第十三章是「爱的篇章」：爱是恒久忍耐又有恩慈，不嫉妒不自夸不张狂，如今常存的有信有望有爱，其中最大的是爱。

第十五章论复活：如果基督没有复活我们的信就是徒然的。但基督已经复活，成为睡了之人初熟的果子，死被得胜吞灭了！这章给面对死亡恐惧的人带来极大安慰。

保罗处理每个问题都回到十字架：分裂？十字架使我们合一。骄傲？十字架使我们谦卑。不道德？十字架显明身体的宝贵。

对你来说，这本书教导：教会不是完美之人聚集的地方，而是不完美的人一起学习跟随基督的地方。关键是谦卑相爱，以十字架为中心。
content_en:
1 Corinthians is Paul's letter to the Corinthian church, written around AD 55. Corinth was a prosperous port city notorious for moral corruption; the church was heavily influenced by secular culture and riddled with problems.

First, divisions (chapters 1-4): some said 'I follow Paul,' others 'I follow Apollos.' Paul rebukes sharply — the church's foundation is Christ, not any preacher. God's wisdom is the cross's message, foolishness to the world but God's saving power.

Then moral issues (chapters 5-6): someone in the church was sexually immoral and the church did nothing. Paul says the body is the Holy Spirit's temple — honor God with it. Chapters 8-10 address food offered to idols — though we have freedom, don't stumble weaker brothers. Love matters more than freedom.

Chapters 12-14 discuss spiritual gifts: the church is Christ's body, every member matters, gifts differ but are equally valuable. Nestled between is chapter 13, the 'love chapter': love is patient, love is kind, it does not envy or boast or be proud. And now these three remain: faith, hope, and love — the greatest is love.

Chapter 15 argues for resurrection: if Christ hasn't been raised, our faith is futile. But Christ HAS been raised, the firstfruits of those who sleep. Death has been swallowed up in victory! This chapter brings immense comfort to those facing the fear of death.

Paul's method for every problem is returning to the cross: Division? The cross unites. Pride? The cross humbles. Immorality? The cross shows the body's preciousness.

For you, this book teaches: church isn't where perfect people gather — it's where imperfect people learn together to follow Christ. The key is humble love centered on the cross.
discussion_questions: 哥林多教会的哪个问题在今天的教会也存在？Which Corinthian church problem exists in churches today?
第13章的爱如何解决教会冲突？How does chapter 13's love solve church conflicts?
属灵恩赐的目的是什么？What's the purpose of spiritual gifts?

title_zh: 以弗所书导读：在基督里的丰盛
content_zh:
以弗所书是保罗在罗马监狱中写的，被称为「基督徒信仰的珠穆朗玛峰」，大约写于公元六十一年。全书分两部分：前三章讲教义（我们是谁），后三章讲实践（怎么活）。

第一章是三位一体的颂赞：圣父在创世以前就拣选了我们，预定我们得儿子名分；圣子用祂的血救赎我们，使罪得赦免；圣灵是我们得基业的凭据和印记。保罗祷告求上帝开启信徒心灵的眼睛。

第二章描述极大反转：我们从前死在过犯中，但上帝有丰富怜悯，叫我们与基督一同活过来。「你们得救是本乎恩，也因着信，不是出于自己，乃是上帝所赐的，也不是出于行为，免得有人自夸。」外邦人和犹太人在基督里合为一体。第三章保罗祷告求信徒明白基督的爱何等长阔高深。

后三章转入实际。第四章论教会合一与恩赐，呼召脱去旧人穿上新人。第五章论圣洁生活和夫妻关系——丈夫爱妻子如同基督爱教会。第六章论亲子关系，最后是全副军装：真理腰带、公义护心镜、平安福音的鞋、信德藤牌、救恩头盔、圣灵宝剑，教导属灵争战是真实的。

整本书主题词是「在基督里」，出现超过三十次。我们的身份、能力、盼望、合一都在基督里。

对你来说，以弗所书让你认识真正的身份：不是世界的标签，而是上帝在基督里给你的——被拣选、被爱、被赦免。知道你是谁，才能活出你该有的样子。
content_en:
Ephesians was written by Paul from a Roman prison, called 'the Mount Everest of Christian faith,' around AD 61. It divides into two halves: the first three chapters cover doctrine (who we are), the last three cover practice (how to live).

Chapter 1 is a Trinitarian doxology: the Father chose us before creation, predestining us for adoption; the Son redeemed us by His blood, granting forgiveness; the Holy Spirit is the guarantee and seal of our inheritance. Paul prays for God to open believers' spiritual eyes.

Chapter 2 describes a dramatic reversal: we were dead in transgressions, but God, rich in mercy, made us alive with Christ. 'For it is by grace you have been saved, through faith — not from yourselves, it is the gift of God — not by works, so that no one can boast.' Gentiles and Jews are united in Christ. Chapter 3 records Paul's prayer that believers may grasp how wide, long, high, and deep is Christ's love.

The final three chapters turn practical. Chapter 4 discusses church unity and gifts, calling believers to put off the old self and put on the new. Chapter 5 addresses holy living and marriage — husbands loving wives as Christ loved the church. Chapter 6 covers parent-child relationships, concluding with the armor of God: belt of truth, breastplate of righteousness, shoes of the Gospel of peace, shield of faith, helmet of salvation, sword of the Spirit — teaching that spiritual warfare is real.

The book's theme phrase is 'in Christ,' appearing over thirty times. Our identity, power, hope, and unity are all in Christ.

For you, Ephesians reveals your true identity: not the world's labels but what God gives you in Christ — chosen, loved, forgiven. Knowing who you are is the foundation for living as you should.
discussion_questions: '在基督里'对你的身份认知有什么影响？How does being 'in Christ' affect your identity?
属灵争战在青少年生活中如何体现？How does spiritual warfare manifest in teenage life?
教会合一为什么这么重要？Why is church unity so important?

title_zh: 腓立比书导读：在基督里的喜乐
content_zh:
腓立比书是保罗在罗马监狱中写给腓立比教会的书信，被称为「喜乐书信」。腓立比教会是保罗在欧洲建立的第一个教会，与他关系亲密，常在经济上支持他。

第一章，保罗分享监狱中的心态：被捆锁反而让福音更广传。他宣告：「因为我活着就是基督，我死了就有益处。」活着继续服侍，死了与基督同在，怎样都好。

第二章有最重要的基督论经文：耶稣本有上帝的形象，却虚己取了奴仆形象，自己卑微顺服以至于死在十字架上，所以上帝将祂升为至高。我们也要以基督的心为心，存谦卑的心看别人比自己强。

第三章是保罗的见证：他曾是法利赛人精英，但认识基督后把一切都当作粪土。「我以认识我主基督耶稣为至宝。」这是彻底翻转的价值观。

第四章教导面对忧虑：「应当一无挂虑，凡事借着祷告祈求感谢告诉上帝，上帝所赐出人意外的平安必保守你们的心。」名言「我靠着那加给我力量的凡事都能做」不是说你能考满分，而是无论富足缺乏都能靠基督知足得胜。

腓立比书告诉我们：真正的喜乐不来自环境而来自认识基督。基督的谦卑虚己是福音核心，我们的回应是以认识祂为至宝。

对你来说，腓立比书回答青少年最常问的问题：怎样才能真正快乐？答案不是成绩好人缘好什么都有，而是认识基督以祂为满足。当基督成为你的至宝，任何环境中都能找到喜乐。
content_en:
Philippians is Paul's letter from a Roman prison to the Philippian church, called the 'joy epistle.' The Philippian church was the first Paul established in Europe, sharing a close relationship and regularly supporting his ministry financially.

In chapter 1, Paul shares his prison mindset: chains actually spread the Gospel further. He declares: 'For to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain.' Living means continued service; dying means being with Christ — either way is good.

Chapter 2 contains the most important Christological passage: Jesus, being in God's nature, didn't grasp equality with God but emptied Himself, taking a servant's form, humbling Himself to death on a cross. Therefore God exalted Him to the highest place. We should have Christ's mindset — humble, considering others better than ourselves.

Chapter 3 is Paul's testimony: once an elite Pharisee, but after knowing Christ he counted everything as rubbish. 'I consider knowing Christ Jesus my Lord as surpassingly valuable.' A completely inverted value system.

Chapter 4 teaches handling anxiety: 'Do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation, by prayer and thanksgiving, present your requests to God. And God's peace, which transcends understanding, will guard your hearts.' The famous 'I can do all things through him who strengthens me' doesn't mean acing every test — it means contentment and victory through Christ in any circumstance.

Philippians teaches: true joy comes not from circumstances but from knowing Christ. Christ's humble self-emptying is the Gospel's core; our response is treasuring Him above all.

For you, Philippians answers teenagers' most common question: How can I be truly happy? Not through grades, popularity, or possessions — but knowing Christ and finding satisfaction in Him. When Christ is your greatest treasure, you find joy anywhere.
discussion_questions: 在困难中如何保持喜乐？How can we maintain joy during difficulties?
基督的谦卑对你有什么挑战？How does Christ's humility challenge you?
什么是真正的知足？What is true contentment?

title_zh: 加拉太书导读：自由的福音
title_en: Galatians Guide: The Gospel of Freedom
content_zh:
加拉太书被称为「基督徒自由的大宪章」，是保罗语气最激烈的书信，写给加拉太地区的教会。这些教会面临严重危机：假教师教导信徒除了信耶稣还必须守犹太律法才能得救。

保罗极其愤怒：「我希奇你们这么快离开那借着基督之恩召你们的，去从别的福音。」他说传不同福音的应当被咒诅——连天使也不例外。篡改福音就是摧毁福音。

第一到二章，保罗为使徒身份辩护，记录当面抵挡彼得的事件：彼得原本与外邦信徒吃饭，犹太人来了就退去，保罗公开指责他否认因信称义。

第三章论证核心：亚伯拉罕因信称义在律法之前四百三十年就有了。律法的目的是像训蒙师傅把人引到基督面前——让人认识自己做不到而需要救主。第四章用比喻说明我们不再是奴仆而是儿子，「上帝差祂儿子的灵进入你们心，呼叫阿爸父！」

第五章强调基督释放我们得自由，但不要用自由放纵情欲。圣灵的果子——仁爱喜乐和平忍耐恩慈良善信实温柔节制——才是真自由的标志。

加拉太书就是在保卫福音：救恩完全是恩典，完全是基督的功劳，不需要加上任何行为。「基督加上别的东西」就是假福音。

对你来说，加拉太书释放你脱离律法主义（靠表现讨上帝喜欢）和放纵主义（既然得救就随便活）。真自由是在基督里靠圣灵活出爱的生命。你不需要「够好」才被上帝爱，你已经被爱了。
content_en:
Galatians is called 'the Magna Carta of Christian freedom' and is Paul's most fiercely worded letter, written to churches in the Galatian region. These churches faced a serious crisis: false teachers taught that believers must follow Jewish law in addition to believing in Jesus for salvation.

Paul was furious: 'I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting the one who called you to live in the grace of Christ and turning to a different gospel.' He says anyone preaching a different gospel should be eternally condemned — angels included. Tampering with the Gospel destroys the Gospel.

Chapters 1-2: Paul defends his apostleship and records confronting Peter face-to-face. Peter had been eating with Gentile believers but withdrew when Jewish Christians arrived. Paul publicly rebuked him for effectively denying justification by faith.

Chapter 3's core argument: Abraham was justified by faith 430 years before the Law. The Law's purpose was to serve as a guardian leading us to Christ — showing we can't do it ourselves and need a Savior. Chapter 4 uses analogy: we're no longer slaves but sons. 'God sent the Spirit of his Son into our hearts, crying "Abba, Father!"'

Chapter 5 emphasizes Christ set us free, but don't use freedom for the flesh. The Spirit's fruit — love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control — marks true freedom.

Galatians IS a defense of the Gospel: salvation is entirely grace, entirely Christ's merit, requiring no human works. 'Christ plus anything' is a false gospel.

For you, Galatians frees you from legalism (performing to earn God's approval) and license (saved so live however). True freedom is in Christ, living love through the Spirit's power. You don't need to be 'good enough' to be loved by God — you're already loved.
discussion_questions: 基督徒的自由包括什么？不包括什么？What does Christian freedom include? What doesn't it include?
为什么律法主义这么有吸引力？Why is legalism so attractive?
如何平衡自由与责任？How do we balance freedom and responsibility?

title_zh: 歌罗西书导读：基督的至上性
content_zh:
歌罗西书是保罗在监狱中写给歌罗西教会的书信，大约写于公元六十一年。教会不是保罗建立的，而是同工以巴弗建立的。当时有人教导混合主义：单单信基督不够，还需要律法规条、天使崇拜、神秘经历和禁欲操练。

保罗直截了当回应：基督就是一切。第一章包含最伟大的基督论宣言：「爱子是那不能看见之上帝的像，是首生的在一切被造的以先。万有都是靠祂造的，又是为祂造的。祂在万有之先，万有也靠祂而立。」基督不只是救主，祂是宇宙创造者和维持者，在凡事上居首位。

第二章警告不要被哲学和虚空妄言欺骗。在基督里有上帝本性一切的丰盛。律法规条只是影儿，形体是基督。不要让人因饮食节期论断你们，也不要被假谦卑和天使崇拜迷惑。

第三章教导新生活：与基督同复活就要思念上面的事。治死淫乱污秽贪婪恼怒，穿上怜悯恩慈谦卑温柔忍耐。在这一切之外要存爱心，爱心是联络全德的。让基督的道理丰丰富富存在心里。

歌罗西书的核心是：基督足够了！祂的救赎完全，地位至上，我们在祂里面已经完全。不需要「基督加上别的东西」。

对你来说，这卷书在充满各种声音的时代特别重要。总有人说基督不够，你还需要别的才能被接纳、成功、满足。但保罗说：在基督里有上帝一切的丰盛，你在祂里面也得了丰盛。抓住基督，祂就是你所需要的一切。
content_en:
Colossians is Paul's prison letter to the Colossian church, written around AD 61. The church was founded not by Paul but by his coworker Epaphras. Some were teaching syncretism: faith in Christ alone wasn't enough — you also needed legal regulations, angel worship, mystical experiences, and ascetic practices.

Paul responds directly: Christ is everything. Chapter 1 contains one of the greatest Christological declarations: 'The Son is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn over all creation. For in him all things were created; all things were created through him and for him. He is before all things, and in him all things hold together.' Christ isn't just Savior — He's the universe's Creator and Sustainer, supreme in everything.

Chapter 2 warns against deception by human philosophy and hollow deception. In Christ all the fullness of Deity dwells bodily. Legal regulations are shadows; the reality is Christ. Don't let anyone judge you by food rules or festivals, and don't be seduced by false humility and angel worship.

Chapter 3 teaches new-life practice: raised with Christ, set your hearts on things above. Put to death immorality, impurity, greed, anger. Clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, patience. Over all these put on love, which binds them in perfect unity. Let Christ's message dwell richly among you.

Colossians' core: Christ is sufficient! His redemption is complete, His position supreme, we are complete in Him. No need for 'Christ plus anything.'

For you, this book is especially important in an age of countless voices. Someone always says Christ isn't enough — you need something else to be accepted, successful, or satisfied. But Paul says: in Christ all God's fullness dwells, and you have fullness in Him. Hold on to Christ — He's everything you need.
discussion_questions: 今天什么东西试图与基督竞争首位？What tries to compete with Christ for first place today?
基督的至上性如何影响你的日常决定？How does Christ's supremacy affect your daily decisions?
'在基督里完全'对你意味着什么？What does being 'complete in Christ' mean to you?

title_zh: 提摩太前书导读：教会生活指南
content_zh:
提摩太前书是保罗写给年轻同工提摩太的教牧书信，大约写于公元六十二到六十四年。提摩太是保罗最亲密的属灵儿子，此时被留在以弗所牧养教会。

第一章警告防备异端——偏离信仰核心沉迷荒渺无凭之话的人。律法的正当用途是显明罪，不是让人靠行为自义。保罗以自己为例：他曾是逼迫教会的罪魁，但蒙了怜悯。

第二章论公共敬拜：要为万人祷告，特别为执政者。上帝愿万人得救明白真道。第三章列出教会领袖的资格：监督和执事的要求主要是品格——无可指责、有节制、善于教导、不贪财。重点不是能力而是品格。

第四章预言末世有人离弃真道。保罗勉励提摩太在敬虔上操练自己，操练身体益处还少，惟独敬虔凡事都有益处。然后是对年轻人最鼓励的话：「不可叫人小看你年轻，总要在言语行为爱心信心清洁上都作信徒的榜样。」

第五章论对待不同年龄段信徒和寡妇照顾。第六章警告贪财：「贪财是万恶之根」，要知足，追求公义敬虔信心爱心忍耐温柔，为真道打那美好的仗。

提摩太前书告诉我们：教会是真理的柱石和根基，教会生活的每个方面都应反映福音真理。

对你来说，提摩太也是年轻人。你不需要等「长大」才能服侍上帝。现在就在品格上操练，在信仰上扎根，在生活中作榜样。上帝使用的不是完美的人，而是愿意被祂塑造的人。
content_en:
1 Timothy is Paul's pastoral letter to young coworker Timothy, written around AD 62-64. Timothy was Paul's closest spiritual son, left in Ephesus to shepherd the church.

Chapter 1 warns against false teaching — those who wander from faith's core into myths and endless genealogies. The Law's proper use is revealing sin, not enabling self-righteousness. Paul uses himself as example: once a persecutor and worst of sinners, yet received mercy.

Chapter 2 addresses public worship: pray for all people, especially authorities. God wants all saved and knowing truth. Chapter 3 details leadership qualifications: overseers and deacons are measured primarily by character — above reproach, temperate, able to teach, not greedy. The emphasis is character, not ability.

Chapter 4 prophesies end-times apostasy. Paul encourages Timothy to train in godliness — physical training has some value, but godliness has value for all things. Then the most encouraging word for youth: 'Don't let anyone look down on you because you are young, but set an example in speech, conduct, love, faith, and purity.'

Chapter 5 discusses treating different age groups and caring for widows. Chapter 6 warns about loving money: 'The love of money is a root of all kinds of evil.' Pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love, endurance, gentleness. Fight the good fight of faith.

1 Timothy teaches: the church is the pillar and foundation of truth; every aspect of church life should reflect Gospel truth.

For you, Timothy was young too. You don't need to wait until you're 'grown up' to serve God. Start now: train in character, root yourself in faith, be an example daily. God doesn't use perfect people — He uses those willing to be shaped by Him.
discussion_questions: 年轻人在教会中可以怎样服侍？How can young people serve in church?
什么是真正的敬虔？What is true godliness?
如何平衡谦卑与做榜样？How do we balance humility with being an example?

title_zh: 提摩太后书导读：最后的嘱托
content_zh:
提摩太后书是保罗生命中最后一封书信，在罗马监狱中写成，不久后他就殉道了，大约写于公元六十六到六十七年。这是一封充满深情的遗书。

第一章鼓励提摩太不要胆怯，不要以福音为耻。「上帝赐给我们不是胆怯的心，乃是刚强仁爱谨守的心。」保罗回忆提摩太从外祖母罗以和母亲友尼基传承的信仰，勉励他把恩赐如火挑旺起来。

第二章用三个比喻描绘忠心事奉：士兵专心效力不被平民事务缠身，运动员按规矩比赛才能得冠冕，农夫劳力才能先得粮食。「你要和我同受苦难，好像基督耶稣的精兵。」事奉需要纪律和勤劳。

第三章预言末世：人专顾自己、贪财、自夸、狂傲、违背父母。面对这一切，保罗的药方是回到圣经：「圣经都是上帝所默示的，于教训督责使人归正教导人学义都是有益的。」这是关于圣经权威最重要的经文之一。

第四章是最感人的嘱托：「务要传道，无论得时不得时。」保罗回顾一生：「那美好的仗我已经打过了，当跑的路我已经跑尽了，所信的道我已经守住了。从此以后有公义的冠冕为我存留。」这是忠心仆人坦然面对死亡的信心宣告。

提摩太后书告诉我们：福音值得为之受苦、坚持、献出生命。保罗不后悔为福音付出的一切。

对你来说，这卷书挑战你：愿意为信仰付出什么代价？同学嘲笑你的时候还愿意为福音站立吗？保罗的榜样说明忠心到底是可能的，因为呼召我们的上帝是信实的。
content_en:
2 Timothy is Paul's final letter, written from a Roman prison shortly before martyrdom, around AD 66-67. It's a deeply personal farewell.

Chapter 1 encourages Timothy not to be timid or ashamed of the Gospel. 'The Spirit God gave us does not make us timid, but gives us power, love, and self-discipline.' Paul recalls the faith passed from Timothy's grandmother Lois and mother Eunice, urging him to fan into flame God's gift.

Chapter 2 uses three analogies for faithful service: a soldier focuses on pleasing the commander without civilian entanglements; an athlete must compete by the rules to win; a farmer must work hard to reap first. 'Join with me in suffering, like a good soldier of Christ Jesus.' Ministry requires discipline and diligence.

Chapter 3 prophesies end times: people will be self-loving, money-loving, boastful, proud, disobedient to parents. Facing this, Paul's prescription is returning to Scripture: 'All Scripture is God-breathed and useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting, and training in righteousness.' This is one of the most important passages on biblical authority.

Chapter 4 is the most moving charge: 'Preach the word; be prepared in season and out of season.' Paul reviews his life: 'I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith. Now there is in store for me the crown of righteousness.' A faithful servant's confident declaration facing death.

2 Timothy teaches: the Gospel is worth suffering for, persevering for, giving your life for. Paul had no regrets.

For you, this book challenges: What will you sacrifice for faith? When classmates mock you, will you still stand for the Gospel? Paul's example shows faithfulness to the end is possible, because the God who called us is faithful.
discussion_questions: 面对困难时你如何不以福音为耻？How do you not be ashamed of the Gospel when facing difficulties?
圣经在你生活中的作用是什么？What role does Scripture play in your life?
你希望在生命终点时能说什么？What do you hope to say at the end of your life?

title_zh: 希伯来书导读：基督更美的约
content_zh:
希伯来书是新约最独特的书信之一，作者不详，写给一群想放弃基督教回归犹太教的犹太基督徒。核心论证：基督和新约在各方面都超越旧约，不要回头。

第一到二章论基督比天使更尊贵：天使是服役的灵，基督是上帝的儿子。但这位至高者成为人，借着死败坏掌死权的魔鬼，释放那些因怕死而为奴的人。

第三到四章论基督比摩西更大：摩西是忠心仆人，基督是管理上帝家的儿子。以色列人因不信倒在旷野，但基督带来真正的安息。上帝的道活泼有功效，比两刃的剑更快。

第五到七章论基督是更美的大祭司：不按亚伦的等次而是按麦基洗德的等次，永远为祭司，圣洁无罪。第八到十章论基督献上更美的祭：牛羊的血不能真正除罪，但基督用自己的血一次献上就成了永远的赎罪祭。新约取代旧约因为是更美的约。

第十一章是「信心英雄榜」：亚伯拉罕、摩西、喇合……因信心而活。第十二章劝勉：既有这许多见证人围着我们，就当放下重担，存心忍耐奔那摆在前头的路程，仰望为我们信心创始成终的耶稣。

希伯来书全面论证基督的福音比旧约一切预表和影儿都更美更完全。

对你来说，这卷书给你坚持信仰的理由：不要回头，你信的不是影子而是实体。当信仰变难想放弃时，记住信心前辈的见证，更要仰望耶稣——祂忍受了十字架如今坐在上帝右边。坚持到底，冠冕在前方。
content_en:
Hebrews is one of the New Testament's most unique letters; its author is unknown, written to Jewish Christians considering abandoning faith to return to Judaism. The central argument: Christ and the new covenant surpass the old in every way — don't turn back.

Chapters 1-2 argue Christ is superior to angels: angels are ministering spirits; Christ is God's Son. Yet this supreme One became human, destroying the devil who holds death's power and freeing those enslaved by death's fear.

Chapters 3-4 argue Christ is greater than Moses: Moses was a faithful servant; Christ is the Son over God's house. Israel fell in the wilderness through unbelief, but Christ brings true rest. God's word is alive and active, sharper than any double-edged sword.

Chapters 5-7 argue Christ is the superior High Priest: not in Aaron's order but Melchizedek's — a priest forever, holy and sinless. Chapters 8-10 argue Christ offered a superior sacrifice: bulls' and goats' blood couldn't truly remove sin, but Christ offered His own blood once for all as the eternal atoning sacrifice. The new covenant replaces the old as a better covenant.

Chapter 11 is the 'faith hall of fame': Abraham, Moses, Rahab... living by faith. Chapter 12 exhorts: since we're surrounded by such a cloud of witnesses, throw off every hindrance, run with perseverance the race before us, fixing our eyes on Jesus, the pioneer and perfecter of faith.

Hebrews comprehensively argues Christ's Gospel is more beautiful and complete than all Old Testament types and shadows.

For you, this book gives a powerful reason to persevere: don't turn back — you believe in substance, not shadow. When faith gets hard and you want to quit, remember the faith heroes' testimony, and above all fix your eyes on Jesus, who endured the cross and now sits at God's right hand. Persevere to the end; the crown awaits.
discussion_questions: 为什么基督比旧约制度更好？Why is Christ better than the Old Testament system?
第11章的信心英雄如何鼓励你？How do the faith heroes in chapter 11 encourage you?
什么会让你想要'回头'？What might tempt you to 'go back'?

title_zh: 启示录导读：最终的胜利
content_zh:
启示录是圣经最后一卷书，由使徒约翰在拔摩岛流放时所写，大约在公元九十五年。这是充满象征语言的启示文学，核心信息清楚：耶稣基督是历史的主宰，邪恶必被审判，上帝子民必得最终胜利。

第一到三章，复活荣耀的基督向七个教会说话：以弗所失去起初的爱，士每拿在苦难中忠心，别迦摩容忍异端，撒狄表面活着实际上死了，非拉铁非力量虽小却忠心，老底嘉不冷不热。这七封信今天仍完全适用。

第四到五章是天上敬拜的壮观异象：被杀的羔羊配得打开七印封严的书卷，因为祂用自己的血从各族各方各民各国买了人来归于上帝。

第六到十九章是审判异象：七印七号七碗描述末日灾难和上帝对罪恶的终极审判。这不是恐怖故事，而是给受苦教会的安慰：上帝在掌权，会为圣徒伸冤，公义终将得胜。

第二十章记千禧年和最后审判。第二十一到二十二章是圣经最美的结局：新天新地，圣城新耶路撒冷，上帝亲自与人同住。「上帝要擦去他们一切的眼泪，不再有死亡悲哀哭号疼痛。」

启示录是福音应许的终极实现：基督十字架的得胜达到高潮，罪死亡撒但被彻底消灭，上帝国度完全降临。被杀的羔羊就是各各他山的耶稣，如今是万王之王万主之主。

对你来说，启示录给你面对未来的勇气。无论世界多黑暗，你经历多少困难，故事结局已经写好——我们赢了。基督已得胜，我们站在胜利者一边。不要害怕不要灰心，坚持信仰等候那天：「主耶稣啊，我愿你来！」
content_en:
Revelation is the Bible's final book, written by the apostle John during exile on Patmos around AD 95. It's apocalyptic literature full of symbolic language, but the core message is clear: Jesus Christ is Lord of history, evil will be judged, and God's people will achieve ultimate victory.

Chapters 1-3: the risen, glorified Christ speaks to seven churches. Ephesus lost its first love; Smyrna remained faithful in suffering; Pergamum tolerated heresy; Sardis appeared alive but was dead; Philadelphia was faithful despite little strength; Laodicea was lukewarm. These seven letters remain completely relevant today.

Chapters 4-5 present spectacular heavenly worship: the slain Lamb is worthy to open the seven-sealed scroll, because with His blood He purchased people for God from every tribe, language, people, and nation.

Chapters 6-19 contain judgment visions: seven seals, seven trumpets, seven bowls depicting end-times disasters and God's ultimate judgment on evil. These aren't horror stories — they're comfort for the suffering church: God is sovereign, He'll vindicate the saints, justice will prevail.

Chapter 20 records the millennium and final judgment. Chapters 21-22 are Scripture's most beautiful ending: new heaven and new earth, the holy city New Jerusalem, God Himself dwelling with people. 'He will wipe every tear from their eyes. There will be no more death or mourning or crying or pain.'

Revelation is the Gospel promise's ultimate fulfillment: Christ's cross-victory reaches its climax — sin, death, and Satan utterly destroyed, God's Kingdom fully arrived. The slain Lamb is the same Jesus from Calvary, now King of kings and Lord of lords.

For you, Revelation gives courage to face the future. No matter how dark the world or how many difficulties you face, the ending is already written — we win. Christ has conquered; we stand with the victor. Don't be afraid, don't lose heart. Hold fast and await that day: 'Come, Lord Jesus!'
discussion_questions: 启示录中的象征如何帮助我们理解属灵真理？How do Revelation's symbols help us understand spiritual truths?
面对苦难时，最终胜利的盼望如何安慰你？How does hope of ultimate victory comfort you during suffering?
新天新地与现在的世界有什么不同？How will the new heaven and earth be different from now?

title_zh: 校园霸凌：在困难中寻求帮助
title_en: School Bullying: Seeking Help in Difficulties
content_zh:
校园霸凌是一个严重的问题，它不仅造成身体上的伤害，更带来深刻的情感创伤。如果你正在经历霸凌，首先请记住：这不是你的错。上帝爱你，祂看见你每一滴眼泪和每一次痛苦。诗篇五十六篇说「我几次流离，你都记数；求你把我眼泪装在你的皮袋里。」你的痛苦在上帝眼中是宝贵的。

面对霸凌，第一步是立即寻求帮助。告诉你的父母、老师或学校辅导员。很多同学不敢说出来，觉得会更丢脸或者遭到报复，但沉默只会让情况更糟。上帝常常通过身边的人来保护我们，寻求帮助不是软弱，而是智慧和勇敢的表现。

第二，记录每一次霸凌事件的时间、地点、内容和证人。这些记录不仅有助于学校调查和解决问题，也能帮助你客观地看待正在发生的事情，而不是被恐惧淹没。

第三，为伤害你的人祷告。这听起来很难，但这不是要你继续忍受欺负，而是为了保护你自己的心不被仇恨和苦毒腐蚀。耶稣在十字架上说「父啊，赦免他们」，祂理解被伤害的感受。当你为霸凌者祷告时，你其实是在释放自己，不让愤怒掌控你的生命。

第四，如果你看到别人被霸凌，要勇敢地站出来或者寻求帮助。沉默有时候就是帮凶。也许你的一句话、一个陪伴，就能改变另一个人的处境。圣经说「行公义，好怜悯」，这正是基督徒在校园里应该做的。

最重要的是，记住你的身份：你是上帝的儿女，有着无限的价值。霸凌者的话语不能定义你是谁。他们可能说你丑、笨、没用，但创造宇宙的上帝说你是祂眼中的珍宝。把你的身份建立在上帝的话语上，而不是别人的评价上。如果你有自残或自杀的想法，请立即告诉你信任的成年人并寻求专业帮助。你的生命是宝贵的，上帝对你有美好的计划。
content_en:
School bullying is a serious problem that causes not just physical harm but deep emotional trauma. If you're experiencing bullying, first remember: this is not your fault. God loves you and sees every tear and every moment of pain. Psalm 56 says, "You keep track of all my sorrows. You have collected all my tears in your bottle." Your pain is precious in God's eyes.

The first step in facing bullying is to immediately seek help. Tell your parents, teachers, or school counselors. Many students are afraid to speak up, thinking it will be more embarrassing or invite retaliation, but silence only makes things worse. God often protects us through the people around us — seeking help isn't weakness but an act of wisdom and courage.

Second, document every bullying incident: the time, place, what happened, and who witnessed it. These records not only help the school investigate and resolve the situation but also help you see what's happening objectively rather than being overwhelmed by fear.

Third, pray for those who hurt you. This sounds incredibly difficult, but it's not about tolerating continued abuse — it's about protecting your own heart from being corroded by hatred and bitterness. Jesus said on the cross, "Father, forgive them." He understands what it feels like to be harmed. When you pray for your bullies, you're actually freeing yourself, refusing to let anger control your life.

Fourth, if you see someone else being bullied, bravely step up or seek help. Silence sometimes makes us accomplices. Perhaps your single word of kindness or act of companionship could change someone's entire situation. The Bible says to "act justly and love mercy" — this is exactly what Christians should do on campus.

Most importantly, remember your identity: you are God's child with infinite worth. A bully's words cannot define who you are. They may call you ugly, stupid, or worthless, but the God who created the universe says you are His treasure. Build your identity on God's Word, not on others' opinions. If you ever have thoughts of self-harm or suicide, immediately tell a trusted adult and seek professional help. Your life is precious, and God has a beautiful plan for you.
discussion_questions: 为什么校园霸凌这么普遍？Why is school bullying so common?
如何帮助被霸凌的同学？How can you help bullied classmates?
面对霸凌时，饶恕和保护自己如何平衡？How do you balance forgiveness and self-protection when facing bullying?

title_zh: 在校园里自然地传福音
content_zh:
向同学传福音常常让人紧张，怕被拒绝或者损害友谊。但福音本来就是好消息，好消息应该自然而喜乐地分享。想想看，如果你发现了一家超好吃的餐厅，你会不会自然地告诉朋友？福音比任何好消息都更值得分享。

最有力的传福音方式其实不是口才，而是你的生命。活出基督的样式——诚实、善良、有爱心、可靠、在压力下仍然有平安——这些会让同学好奇你为什么不一样。当别人都在抱怨考试时你能保持平静，当同学遇到困难时你主动帮助，这些日常的小事就是最好的见证。保罗说「你们是我们的荐信，写在我们的心上，被众人所知道所念诵的。」

其次，建立真诚的友谊。不要把同学只看作「传福音对象」，要真心关心他们的生活、学业、烦恼。如果朋友觉得你只是为了让他信教才跟他来往，这会让人非常反感。真正的爱是不带条件的，即使对方最终不接受福音，你们依然是朋友。

第三，分享而不是争论。比起跟人辩论上帝是否存在，不如说出上帝在你生命中具体做了什么。比如「我以前考试特别焦虑，但信主之后学会了把压力交给上帝，真的平安了很多。」个人见证比任何神学辩论都更有说服力，因为没有人可以否认你自己的经历。

第四，善用各种机会邀请同学参加活动：青年聚会、圣诞晚会、夏令营、运动会。在轻松的环境中接触福音更容易被接受。很多人第一次走进教会不是因为听了一场布道，而是因为朋友的邀请。

第五，为同学恳切祷告。圣灵的工作比你的口才重要一万倍。你负责撒种和浇灌，让种子生长的是上帝自己。不要因为被拒绝就灰心，有些人可能需要很长时间才会信主。你今天种下的种子，也许多年后才会发芽。要有耐心，继续做一个忠心的好朋友。
content_en:
Sharing the Gospel with classmates often makes people nervous — fear of rejection or damaging friendships. But the Gospel is good news, and good news should be shared naturally and joyfully. Think about it: if you discovered an amazing restaurant, wouldn't you naturally tell your friends? The Gospel is worth sharing far more than any other good news.

The most powerful form of evangelism isn't eloquence — it's your life. Living like Christ — honest, kind, loving, reliable, peaceful under pressure — makes classmates wonder why you're different. When everyone's complaining about exams and you remain calm, when you help a struggling classmate without being asked — these everyday moments are the best witness. Paul wrote, "You yourselves are our letter, written on our hearts, known and read by everyone."

Second, build genuine friendships. Don't view classmates merely as "evangelism targets" — truly care about their lives, studies, and struggles. If friends sense you're only befriending them to convert them, it creates deep resentment. True love is unconditional — even if someone never accepts the Gospel, you remain friends.

Third, share rather than argue. Instead of debating whether God exists, tell what God has specifically done in your life. For example: "I used to be extremely anxious about exams, but after coming to faith I learned to surrender my stress to God, and I genuinely feel much more at peace." Personal testimony is more persuasive than any theological debate because no one can deny your own experience.

Fourth, use opportunities to invite classmates to activities: youth gatherings, Christmas celebrations, summer camps, sports events. Encountering the Gospel in relaxed settings is easier to receive. Many people first walk into church not because they heard a sermon but because a friend invited them.

Fifth, pray earnestly for your classmates. The Holy Spirit's work is ten thousand times more important than your eloquence. Your job is to plant and water — God Himself makes the seed grow. Don't be discouraged by rejection. Some people may need years before they come to faith. The seed you plant today may not sprout for many years. Be patient and continue being a faithful, loving friend.
discussion_questions: 你觉得向同学传福音最大的障碍是什么？What do you think is the biggest obstacle to evangelizing classmates?
分享见证和争论教义有什么区别？What's the difference between sharing testimony and arguing doctrine?
如何在不伤害友谊的前提下分享信仰？How do you share faith without damaging friendships?

title_zh: 时间管理：在忙碌中亲近上帝
title_en: Time Management: Drawing Near to God When Busy
content_zh:
青少年的生活真的很忙：学校课程、作业堆积、大小考试、课外活动、社交聚会……感觉每天都像在赶时间。在这样的忙碌中，与上帝的关系很容易被挤到日程表的最后面，甚至完全被忽略。但忙碌不是远离上帝的借口，反而是你更需要上帝的信号。

首先要明白一个重要的优先次序原则：把上帝放在第一位，不是说你每天必须花两个小时读经祷告才算合格。质量比数量重要得多。每天即使只有十五分钟安静地与上帝独处，读几节经文、做一个简短的祷告，也比一周才挤出一次长时间灵修更好。耶稣自己说「你们先求祂的国和祂的义，这些东西都要加给你们了。」当你把上帝放在首位，祂会帮助你更有智慧地管理其余的时间。

其次，学会利用碎片时间来亲近上帝。走路上学时可以听赞美诗或圣经朗读，等公交车时默想一节经文，排队买饭时在心里做个简短的感恩祷告，睡前花两分钟回顾今天上帝的恩典。这些看似微小的操练，积累起来却能深刻地改变你与上帝的关系。

第三，刻意安排安息的时间。上帝设立安息日不是为了限制我们，而是因为祂知道我们需要休息。即使课业再繁忙，也要给自己留出定期休息和敬拜的时间。一个不休息的人最终会崩溃，就像一台不停运转的机器最终会坏掉。

第四，把学习本身变成亲近上帝的机会。做作业之前花三十秒祷告求智慧，学习生物时惊叹上帝创造的精妙，读历史时看见上帝在人类故事中的作为。当你学会在日常事务中看见上帝，你就不再需要把「属灵生活」和「日常生活」分开了。

第五，找到属灵同伴。和其他基督徒同学一起学习，互相鼓励、彼此代祷。一个人很容易懈怠，但团队的力量能帮助你在忙碌中保持与上帝的亲密关系。正如圣经所说「两个人总比一个人好」。
content_en:
Teenage life is genuinely busy: classes, piling homework, endless exams, extracurricular activities, social gatherings — every day feels like a race against the clock. In all this busyness, your relationship with God easily gets pushed to the bottom of your schedule or completely forgotten. But busyness isn't an excuse to drift from God — it's actually a signal that you need Him more.

First, understand an important priority principle: putting God first doesn't mean you must spend two hours daily in Bible study and prayer to qualify. Quality matters far more than quantity. Even just fifteen minutes of quiet time with God daily — reading a few verses, saying a brief prayer — is better than squeezing in one long devotional session per week. Jesus Himself said, "Seek first His kingdom and His righteousness, and all these things will be given to you." When you put God first, He helps you manage the rest of your time more wisely.

Second, learn to use fragments of time to draw near to God. Listen to worship music or Bible audio while walking to school, meditate on a verse while waiting for the bus, say a quick gratitude prayer while standing in the lunch line, spend two minutes before sleep reflecting on God's grace that day. These seemingly small practices, accumulated over time, can profoundly transform your relationship with God.

Third, intentionally schedule rest. God established the Sabbath not to restrict us but because He knows we need rest. No matter how heavy the coursework, leave yourself regular time for rest and worship. A person who never rests will eventually collapse, just like a machine running nonstop will eventually break down.

Fourth, turn studying itself into an opportunity to draw near to God. Spend thirty seconds praying for wisdom before homework, marvel at God's intricate creation while studying biology, see God's hand in human history while reading textbooks. When you learn to see God in everyday tasks, you no longer need to separate "spiritual life" from "daily life."

Fifth, find spiritual companions. Study with other Christian classmates, encourage each other, and pray for one another. It's easy to slack off alone, but the strength of community helps you maintain intimacy with God amid busyness. As Scripture says, "Two are better than one."
discussion_questions: 忙碌时你如何保持与上帝的关系？How do you maintain relationship with God when busy?
什么活动经常挤占你的灵修时间？What activities often crowd out your devotional time?
如何在学习中经历上帝的同在？How do you experience God's presence while studying?

title_zh: 毕业方向：寻求上帝的引导
content_zh:
选专业、选学校、选职业方向，这些都是人生重大的决定，可能影响你未来很多年的道路。面对这些选择，焦虑是很正常的反应。但作为基督徒，你有一个特殊的优势：你可以寻求创造你的上帝的引导。祂比你更了解你自己，也比你更关心你的未来。

首先，祷告求智慧，但同时也要积极行动。很多同学等着上帝给一个超自然的异象或梦，然后才愿意迈出一步。但上帝通常是在我们行走的过程中引导方向，而不是在我们停下来的时候显明整张地图。就像开车时导航会在你行驶中不断给出下一步指令，上帝也在你努力探索的过程中逐步向你显明祂的心意。

其次，花时间认识自己。上帝给每个人不同的恩赐、兴趣、性格和热情，这些都不是随机的，而是祂独特设计的一部分。你擅长什么？做什么事情让你感到充实和喜乐？什么样的工作能让你发挥上帝给你的才能来服侍他人？认真思考这些问题，做一些职业测评，尝试不同的活动和实习机会。

第三，咨询有智慧的人。箴言说「不先商议，所谋无效；谋士众多，所谋乃成。」跟你的父母、老师、牧师、学长学姐认真谈谈。他们的人生经验和从旁观者角度的观察，往往能看到你自己看不到的东西。

第四，不要把「荣耀上帝」局限在全职服侍。上帝呼召一些人做传道人，但祂同样呼召人做医生、工程师、老师、艺术家、企业家。任何职业都可以成为荣耀上帝和服侍邻舍的平台。关键不是你做什么工作，而是你带着什么样的心态去做。

第五，注意内心的平安。上帝的引导通常伴随着一种深层的平安，不是说没有紧张或不确定，而是一种「虽然前路不明，但我知道上帝在掌管」的信心。如果一个选择让你持续感到极度不安，需要认真祷告分辨。

第六，保持开放和灵活。你的人生计划可能会改变，这完全没关系。上帝的道路高过我们的道路。即使走了一段弯路，上帝也有能力让万事互相效力，叫爱祂的人得益处。
content_en:
Choosing a major, school, or career direction are major life decisions that may shape your path for many years. Feeling anxious about these choices is completely normal. But as a Christian, you have a special advantage: you can seek guidance from the God who created you. He knows you better than you know yourself and cares about your future more than you do.

First, pray for wisdom while also taking active steps. Many students wait for a supernatural vision or dream before taking any action. But God typically guides our direction while we're walking, not while we're standing still. Like a GPS giving turn-by-turn directions while you drive, God reveals His will progressively as you actively explore.

Second, spend time understanding yourself. God gave each person different gifts, interests, personality, and passions — none of these are random but part of His unique design. What are you good at? What activities make you feel fulfilled and joyful? What kind of work would let you use God-given talents to serve others? Seriously consider these questions, take career assessments, and try different activities and internship opportunities.

Third, consult wise people. Proverbs says, "Plans fail for lack of counsel, but with many advisers they succeed." Have serious conversations with your parents, teachers, pastors, and older students. Their life experience and outside perspective often reveal things you can't see yourself.

Fourth, don't limit "glorifying God" to full-time ministry. God calls some to be pastors, but He equally calls people to be doctors, engineers, teachers, artists, and entrepreneurs. Any profession can be a platform for glorifying God and serving neighbors. What matters isn't what job you do but the attitude with which you do it.

Fifth, pay attention to inner peace. God's guidance usually comes with a deep sense of peace — not the absence of nervousness or uncertainty, but a confidence that says "though the road ahead is unclear, I know God is in control." If a choice brings persistent extreme unease, take time to pray and discern carefully.

Sixth, stay open and flexible. Your life plans may change, and that's perfectly fine. God's ways are higher than ours. Even if you take some detours, God can work all things together for the good of those who love Him.

title_zh: 情绪管理：在基督里的内心平静
title_en: Emotional Management: Inner Peace in Christ
content_zh:
青少年时期情绪起伏特别大，这很正常但也确实很痛苦。前一秒还开心，下一秒可能就莫名其妙地低落。愤怒、悲伤、恐惧、兴奋、孤独、焦虑……这些情绪翻涌如潮水，让人感觉快要被淹没。但你需要知道：情绪本身不是罪，它们是上帝赐给我们的礼物，帮助我们感知和回应这个世界。问题不在于有情绪，而在于如何管理情绪。

首先，承认情绪的存在，不要压抑它们。很多人觉得基督徒应该永远喜乐，所以不敢承认自己的愤怒、悲伤或恐惧。但看看诗篇吧，大卫向上帝倾诉各种情绪——从极度的喜乐到深深的绝望，从愤怒的呐喊到安静的信靠。上帝从来没有说「不准有负面情绪」，祂说的是「把你的一切忧虑卸给祂，因为祂顾念你。」

其次，学会探索情绪背后的原因。愤怒的背后常常隐藏着受伤，恐惧的背后可能是不安全感，悲伤也许来自失去或失望。当你能辨认出情绪的根源，你就更能对症下药，而不是被情绪的表面所欺骗。

第三，学会在冲动时暂停。当怒气上涌的时候，给自己数到十的时间。雅各书说「人的怒气并不成就上帝的义」，冲动之下说出的话、做出的事往往会让你后悔。暂停不是压抑，而是给自己空间去选择更好的回应方式。在那几秒钟里，你可以默默祷告「主啊，帮助我。」

第四，寻找健康的情绪出口。运动是非常好的选择，跑步、打球、游泳都能释放压力。写日记可以帮助你整理混乱的思绪。音乐，特别是敬拜音乐，能在情绪低谷时给你力量。与你信任的人倾诉也很重要，不要把所有的情绪都闷在心里。

第五，在最困难的情绪中寻求上帝。祂理解你的每一种感受，因为耶稣在世时也经历过人类的所有情绪——祂哭过、愤怒过、忧伤过、惧怕过。你不需要假装坚强，只需要来到祂面前，把真实的自己交给祂。记住，你的身份不是由情绪定义的。你是被上帝所爱的孩子，这个事实不会因为你今天心情好坏而改变。
content_en:
Teenage emotions fluctuate intensely — this is normal but genuinely painful. One moment you're happy, the next you might feel inexplicably low. Anger, sadness, fear, excitement, loneliness, anxiety — these emotions surge like tides, making you feel like you're drowning. But you need to know: emotions themselves aren't sinful. They're gifts from God that help us perceive and respond to the world. The issue isn't having emotions but how we manage them.

First, acknowledge your emotions — don't suppress them. Many people think Christians should always be joyful, so they're afraid to admit anger, sadness, or fear. But look at the Psalms: David poured out every kind of emotion to God — from extreme joy to deep despair, from angry cries to quiet trust. God never said "no negative emotions allowed." He said, "Cast all your anxiety on Him because He cares for you."

Second, learn to explore the causes behind your emotions. Behind anger often hides hurt; behind fear may lie insecurity; sadness might come from loss or disappointment. When you can identify the root of an emotion, you can address the real issue rather than being deceived by surface feelings.

Third, learn to pause when impulses strike. When anger surges, give yourself time to count to ten. James says, "Human anger does not produce the righteousness that God desires." Words spoken and actions taken in impulse often lead to regret. Pausing isn't suppression — it's giving yourself space to choose a better response. In those few seconds, you can silently pray, "Lord, help me."

Fourth, find healthy emotional outlets. Exercise is excellent — running, playing sports, swimming all release stress. Journaling helps organize chaotic thoughts. Music, especially worship music, gives strength during emotional lows. Talking to someone you trust is also important — don't bottle everything up inside.

Fifth, seek God in your most difficult emotions. He understands every feeling you have because Jesus experienced all human emotions during His earthly life — He wept, felt anger, experienced sorrow, and knew fear. You don't need to pretend to be strong; just come before Him and bring your true self. Remember, your identity isn't defined by emotions. You are a child loved by God, and that fact doesn't change based on whether you're having a good or bad day.

title_zh: 身份认同：我是谁？
content_zh:
青少年时期最大的问题之一就是「我到底是谁？」这个问题可能在你换学校、交新朋友、面对同伴压力或者对镜子里的自己不满意时变得特别强烈。社会不断地告诉你：你是你的成绩单、你的外表、你在社交媒体上的粉丝数、你的才能、你的受欢迎程度。如果这些够好，你就有价值；如果不够好，你就不够格。这是一个巨大的谎言。

上帝对你身份的定义截然不同，而且远比这些深刻。首先，你是上帝按照祂自己的形象创造的。创世记告诉我们，上帝造人的时候，把祂自己的形象印在了每一个人身上。无论你觉得自己多么普通、多么不起眼，你都带着造物主的生命印记。这赋予你一种任何人都无法夺去的尊严和价值。

其次，如果你已经信靠了基督，你的身份就更加丰富了。你是上帝的儿女——不是因为你表现好才被接纳，而是因为基督替你付了代价。你是基督的朋友、圣灵的殿堂、天国的公民。这些身份不会因为你考试失败、被同学嘲笑或者长了一脸痘痘而改变。你最糟糕的一天也不能改变上帝对你的爱。

第三，你有独特的呼召和恩赐。上帝造你不是为了让你成为另一个人的复制品，而是要你成为最好的你自己。也许你不是最聪明的学生，但你可能是最有同理心的朋友。也许你不擅长运动，但你可能有惊人的艺术天赋。发现并发展上帝放在你里面的独特恩赐，这是一段美好的旅程。

第四，你的价值不需要你去证明。在这个充满竞争的世界里，我们总觉得必须通过成就来「赚取」自己的价值。但耶稣在十字架上已经宣告了你的价值——祂用自己的生命换取你的生命，这就是你值多少。你不需要更多的奖杯、更高的分数或者更多的点赞来证明自己。

第五，身份的迷茫是成长的正常部分，不要因此害怕或焦虑。探索和提问都是好的。但关键是你把身份建造在什么根基上。建造在成绩上的身份会在失败时崩塌，建造在外表上的身份会随年龄衰退，建造在别人评价上的身份会随风摇摆。唯有建造在上帝话语上的身份，才能在一切风暴中屹立不倒。正如耶稣所说，把房子建在磐石上的人，无论风吹雨打都不会倒塌。
content_en:
One of the biggest questions during teenage years is "Who am I really?" This question becomes especially intense when you change schools, make new friends, face peer pressure, or feel dissatisfied with the person in the mirror. Society constantly tells you: you are your report card, your appearance, your social media followers, your talents, your popularity. If these are good enough, you have value; if not, you don't qualify. This is a massive lie.

God's definition of your identity is completely different and far deeper. First, you are created in God's own image. Genesis tells us that when God made humans, He imprinted His own image on every person. No matter how ordinary or invisible you feel, you carry the Creator's mark. This gives you a dignity and worth that no one can ever take away.

Second, if you've trusted in Christ, your identity becomes even richer. You are God's child — accepted not because you performed well but because Christ paid the price for you. You are Christ's friend, the Holy Spirit's temple, a citizen of heaven. These identities don't change because you failed a test, got mocked by classmates, or broke out in acne. Your worst day cannot change God's love for you.

Third, you have unique calling and gifts. God didn't create you to be a copy of someone else but to be the best version of yourself. Maybe you're not the smartest student, but you might be the most empathetic friend. Maybe you're not athletic, but you might have amazing artistic talent. Discovering and developing the unique gifts God placed in you is a beautiful journey.

Fourth, your value doesn't need proving. In this competitive world, we constantly feel we must "earn" our worth through achievements. But Jesus declared your value on the cross — He exchanged His life for yours, and that's what you're worth. You don't need more trophies, higher scores, or more likes to prove yourself.

Fifth, identity confusion is a normal part of growing up — don't be afraid or anxious about it. Exploration and questioning are good. But the key is what foundation you build your identity on. Identity built on grades collapses when you fail; identity built on appearance fades with age; identity built on others' opinions sways with the wind. Only identity built on God's Word stands firm through every storm. As Jesus said, the one who builds their house on the rock will not fall no matter how hard the wind blows and rain pours.

title_zh: 恋爱观：在爱情中荣耀上帝
title_en: Dating Perspective: Glorifying God in Romance
content_zh:
青少年对恋爱充满好奇和渴望，这非常自然。上帝创造了人与人之间的吸引力和爱的能力，这本身是美好的。但我们所处的文化给了我们许多扭曲的恋爱观：以自我为中心、以身体的欢愉为目标、把关系当作可以随时丢弃的消费品。基督徒的恋爱观建立在完全不同的根基上。

首先，恋爱的目的不只是让你快乐，更是帮助你成为更像基督的人。一段好的关系会激励你在品格上成长、在信仰上更深、在服侍上更热心。如果一段关系让你远离上帝、妥协原则、变得更自私，那就需要认真反思了。

其次，纯洁很重要，这不是过时的老观念。身体的亲密是上帝特别留给婚姻的礼物，它表达最深层的委身和信任。提前享用这个礼物，就像在圣诞节前拆开礼物一样，会失去它本来的意义和美好。保守纯洁不是因为身体是肮脏的，恰恰相反，是因为它太珍贵了。设立明确的身体界限，不要让自己置于试探之中。

第三，在选择交往对象时要有智慧。不要只看外表或一时的感觉，要认真考察对方的品格。这个人爱上帝吗？有诚实正直的品性吗？对家人和朋友怎样？在压力下表现如何？圣经说「不要与不信的人同负一轭」，这不是说不能跟非基督徒做朋友，而是在生命最亲密的关系中，信仰的一致非常重要。

第四，让你信任的长辈参与你的感情生活。父母、牧师、导师的智慧是宝贵的。恋爱很容易让人盲目，而旁观者往往能看到你看不到的问题。这不是让他们控制你的选择，而是借助他们的经验来保护你。

第五，如果你现在还没有预备好恋爱，那就安心等候。单身的季节不是浪费时间，而是上帝给你成长、服侍、预备自己的宝贵机会。先成为对的人，才能遇到对的人。用这段时间学习爱上帝、爱自己、爱身边的人。上帝的时间表永远比你自己的更好。
content_en:
Teenagers are naturally curious about and eager for romance. God created the capacity for attraction and love between people, and this is inherently beautiful. But our culture presents many distorted views of dating: self-centered, focused on physical pleasure, treating relationships as disposable consumer goods. The Christian view of romance is built on an entirely different foundation.

First, the purpose of dating isn't just to make you happy but to help you become more like Christ. A good relationship inspires growth in character, deepens faith, and increases passion for service. If a relationship pulls you away from God, compromises your principles, or makes you more selfish, it's time for serious reflection.

Second, purity matters — this isn't an outdated notion. Physical intimacy is God's special gift reserved for marriage, expressing the deepest commitment and trust. Enjoying this gift prematurely is like opening Christmas presents early — it loses its intended meaning and beauty. Guarding purity isn't because the body is dirty; quite the opposite — it's because it's too precious. Set clear physical boundaries and don't place yourself in tempting situations.

Third, choose dating partners wisely. Don't just look at appearance or momentary feelings — seriously examine the other person's character. Does this person love God? Do they have honesty and integrity? How do they treat family and friends? How do they respond under pressure? The Bible says "do not be unequally yoked with unbelievers" — this doesn't mean you can't befriend non-Christians, but in life's most intimate relationship, unity in faith is critically important.

Fourth, involve trusted elders in your romantic life. The wisdom of parents, pastors, and mentors is invaluable. Romance easily blinds us, while outside observers often see problems we can't. This isn't about letting them control your choices but leveraging their experience to protect you.

Fifth, if you're not ready for dating, wait peacefully. The single season isn't wasted time but God's precious opportunity for growth, service, and self-preparation. Become the right person before trying to find the right person. Use this time to learn to love God, love yourself, and love those around you. God's timetable is always better than your own.

title_zh: 与父母关系：在成长中honor parents
title_en: Parent Relationship: Honoring Parents While Growing
content_zh:
青少年与父母的关系常常很复杂也很矛盾：你渴望独立，他们担心你的安全；你觉得他们不理解你，他们觉得你越来越叛逆；你想要自己做决定，他们总想替你安排一切。这种张力是成长过程中非常正常的现象，但上帝在这件事上给了我们一条清晰的诫命：「当孝敬父母」，而且圣经特别指出这是第一条带应许的诫命。

怎样在追求独立的过程中仍然孝敬父母呢？首先，试着去理解他们的心。你可能觉得他们的规矩烦人、限制太多，但大多数时候这些限制来自爱而非控制。他们曾经也是青少年，经历过你正在经历的挣扎，也犯过他们希望你避免的错误。当你能从爱的角度去理解他们的动机时，很多冲突就会减少。

其次，用沟通代替叛逆。与其偷偷摸摸做他们不允许的事，不如坐下来认真谈谈。告诉他们你的想法和感受，同时也耐心倾听他们的顾虑。试着一起找到折衷的方案。沟通需要技巧：选择合适的时机，不要在双方情绪激动时谈话，用「我觉得……」而不是「你总是……」来表达。

第三，通过在小事上的忠心来赢得更大的信任和自由。准时回家、诚实告知行踪、负责任地完成分内的事——这些看似不起眼的行为会逐渐向父母证明你正在成熟。信任是一点一滴积累起来的，不能强求，但可以通过持续的忠心来赢得。

第四，为你和父母之间的具体问题祷告。有些亲子冲突可能有更深层的属灵根源，需要上帝的智慧和恩典来化解。祷告也会软化你自己的心，帮助你看到自己的问题而不只是对方的错。

第五，即使你不同意父母的决定，也要保持尊重。不用伤人的话语攻击他们，不摔门，不冷战。你可以表达不同意见，但方式很重要。一个在不同意时仍然保持尊重的青少年，远比一个只在顺心时才听话的人更成熟。

最后，记住这是一个暂时的阶段。你与父母的关系会随着你的成长而不断变化。有一天当你回头看，你很可能会感谢他们的引导和保护。珍惜与父母在一起的时光，因为这些日子比你想象的更快就会过去。
content_en:
The teenager-parent relationship is often complex and contradictory: you crave independence while they worry about your safety; you feel they don't understand you while they think you're becoming rebellious; you want to make your own decisions while they try to arrange everything. This tension is perfectly normal during growth, but God gives us a clear commandment: "Honor your parents" — and Scripture specifically notes this is the first commandment with a promise.

How do you honor parents while pursuing independence? First, try to understand their hearts. You might find their rules annoying and restrictions excessive, but most of the time these limits come from love, not control. They were once teenagers too, experienced the struggles you're going through, and made mistakes they hope you'll avoid. When you understand their motives from a perspective of love, many conflicts diminish.

Second, replace rebellion with communication. Rather than secretly doing what they forbid, sit down for an honest conversation. Share your thoughts and feelings while patiently hearing their concerns. Try to find compromise together. Communication takes skill: choose the right timing, don't talk when emotions are heated, use "I feel..." rather than "You always..."

Third, earn greater trust and freedom through faithfulness in small things. Coming home on time, honestly sharing your whereabouts, responsibly completing your duties — these seemingly small actions gradually prove to your parents that you're maturing. Trust is built drop by drop; it can't be demanded but can be earned through consistent faithfulness.

Fourth, pray about specific issues between you and your parents. Some parent-child conflicts may have deeper spiritual roots requiring God's wisdom and grace to resolve. Prayer also softens your own heart, helping you see your own faults rather than only the other person's mistakes.

Fifth, maintain respect even when you disagree with your parents' decisions. Don't attack them with hurtful words, slam doors, or give the silent treatment. You can express disagreement, but the manner matters. A teenager who remains respectful during disagreement is far more mature than one who only obeys when things go their way.

Finally, remember this is a temporary phase. Your relationship with your parents will continuously evolve as you grow. Someday looking back, you'll likely be grateful for their guidance and protection. Treasure the time you have together — these days pass faster than you imagine.

title_zh: 孤独感：在独处中遇见上帝
content_zh:
现代社会有一个奇怪的矛盾：我们通过手机和网络比以往任何时候都更紧密地「连接」在一起，却也比以往任何时候都更加孤独。青少年特别容易感到孤独，尤其当你刷社交媒体看到别人似乎都有一群好朋友、精彩的生活，而你觉得自己被遗忘在角落里。这种感觉真的很痛苦，但你需要知道：孤独本身并不一定是坏事，它可以成为驱使你更深地亲近上帝的动力。

首先，要区分独处和孤独感。独处是你主动选择一个人安静下来，这是健康的、有益的。耶稣自己就经常退到旷野独处，与天父交通。但孤独感是一种被隔绝、不被理解、不被接纳的痛苦体验。认清你正在经历的是哪一种，会帮助你做出合适的回应。

其次，把孤独的时间变成亲近上帝的机会。当周围没有人的时候，正是你和上帝最亲密对话的时刻。读经、祷告、安静敬拜、写灵修日记。上帝应许说「我总不撇下你，也不丢弃你。」即使全世界都忘了你，创造宇宙的上帝永远不会。祂不只是远在天上的神，更是此刻就在你身边、与你同在的父亲。

第三，对自己的感受保持诚实。不要假装你不孤独，不要用忙碌来逃避这种感觉。把你的孤独坦诚地告诉上帝，祂完全理解。诗篇中大卫多次表达孤独和被遗弃的感受，上帝没有责备他，反而回应了他。耶稣在十字架上也经历了终极的孤独，祂呼喊说「我的上帝，为什么离弃我？」——祂比任何人都理解你的感受。

第四，主动关怀身边的人。这听起来有点反常，但有时候治愈孤独最好的方法不是等别人来找你，而是你先迈出第一步去关心别人。也许你身边就有和你一样孤独的人，你的一句问候、一个微笑、一次邀请可能改变他们的一天。

第五，积极加入群体。参加教会青年团契、志愿者活动、学校社团、兴趣小组。真正的友谊需要时间来建立，不要因为第一次参加就觉得融不进去而放弃。坚持去，慢慢地你会找到属于你的群体。记住，孤独是暂时的季节，但你与上帝的关系是永恒的。
content_en:
Modern society has a strange paradox: through phones and the internet, we're more "connected" than ever, yet also lonelier than ever. Teenagers are especially prone to loneliness, particularly when scrolling social media and seeing everyone else seemingly having great friend groups and exciting lives while you feel forgotten in a corner. This feeling is genuinely painful, but you need to know: loneliness itself isn't necessarily bad — it can become the force that drives you deeper into intimacy with God.

First, distinguish between solitude and loneliness. Solitude is actively choosing to be quiet and alone — this is healthy and beneficial. Jesus Himself frequently withdrew to desolate places for communion with the Father. But loneliness is the painful experience of feeling isolated, misunderstood, and unaccepted. Recognizing which you're experiencing helps you respond appropriately.

Second, transform lonely times into opportunities for closeness with God. When no one is around, that's precisely the moment for your most intimate conversation with God. Read Scripture, pray, worship quietly, write a devotional journal. God promises, "I will never leave you nor forsake you." Even if the whole world forgets you, the God who created the universe never will. He's not just a God far away in heaven but a Father right beside you at this very moment.

Third, stay honest about your feelings. Don't pretend you're not lonely; don't use busyness to escape the feeling. Tell God openly about your loneliness — He completely understands. David expressed feelings of loneliness and abandonment many times in the Psalms; God didn't rebuke him but responded. Jesus on the cross experienced the ultimate loneliness, crying out "My God, why have you forsaken me?" — He understands your feelings better than anyone.

Fourth, proactively care for people around you. This sounds counterintuitive, but sometimes the best cure for loneliness isn't waiting for others to find you but taking the first step to care for someone else. Perhaps someone nearby is just as lonely as you — your greeting, smile, or invitation might change their entire day.

Fifth, actively join communities. Participate in church youth groups, volunteer activities, school clubs, hobby groups. True friendship takes time to build — don't give up just because you felt like an outsider the first time. Keep showing up, and gradually you'll find your people. Remember, loneliness is a temporary season, but your relationship with God is eternal.
